title: Partial Dependence can raise TypeConversionError if non-integer grid values are produced for IntegerNullable column

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Currently in partial dependence, if you are calculating the partial dependence for an Integer logical type column, when we get the grid values with _grid_from_X, if there are more unique values in the integer column than the grid resolution, we calculate grid values to use with mscipy.sttats.mquantiles. This can introduce fractional values. With the Integer logical type, we can set a column with fractional values to the int64 dtype and pandas will truncate the value. Our IntegerNullable logical type, which uses Int64 dtype, on the other hand, does not allow that. Because of this, we’ll need to make some change to allow partial dependence on IntegerNullable columns (I don’t view this as an integer nullable incompatibility, since I think pandas is probably right to not just silently truncate your data).

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
    y = ww.init_series(pd.Series([True, False]*25), logical_type="Boolean")
    X = pd.DataFrame({
        "col": pd.Series(range(len(y)))
    })
    X.ww.init(logical_types={"col": "IntegerNullable"})

    pipeline = logistic_regression_binary_pipeline

    pipeline.fit(X, y)
    partial_dependence(
        pipeline,
        X,
        grid_resolution=10,
        features="col",
    )
```
We will need to handle the IntegerNullable case, and while we're doing that, we should make the handling of fractional values for Integer columns explicit by rounding instead of letting the values get truncated.

title: RootMeanSquaredError raises `TypeError: loop of ufunc does not support argument 0 of type int which has no callable sqrt method` when Nullable types are used

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Similar to https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/3919 and https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/3920, we are seeing an error when Nullable types are forcibly used in AutomlSearch that comes from the conversion to the `object` dtype when converting data with nullable pandas dtypes to numpy arrays. 

In this case, it is because `metrics.mean_squared_error` uses `np.sqrt` under the hood, which will raise `TypeError: loop of ufunc does not support argument 0 of type int which has no callable sqrt method` when data with an `object` dtype is passed in. 

This can be reproduced as follows:
```python
    import woodwork as ww

    X, y = X_y_binary
    y_n = ww.init_series(y, logical_type="IntegerNullable")
    root_obj = RootMeanSquaredError()
    root_obj.objective_function(y_n, y_n)
```

If we handle nullable types for all objective functions in #3919, though, and not just for `validate_data`, we shouldn't need any additional handling for this error to go away.

Note: This _can_ currently be seen in AutoMLSearch, despite the presence of the replace nullable types component. See https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/3739

title: Review usage of `np.testing.assert_allclose` across repo with increased usage of nullable types

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Numpy functions like `isnan` and `isfinite` result in errors when numpy data with the `object` dtype is passed in. When pandas' nullable extension types (such as `boolean` and `Int64`) are converted `pd.DataFrame.to_numpy`, they get the `object` dtype. 

Because of this, the `assert_allclose` testing function in numpy results in the following error when data with nullable dtypes are passed in: `TypeError: ufunc 'isfinite' not supported for the input types, and the inputs could not be safely coerced to any supported types according to the casting rule ''safe''`

We use this testing function in a number of places across EvalML's tests, so if we are p[lanning on increasing usage of the nullable woodwork logical types, we will likely need to reconsider usage of this function.

title: ObjectiveBase raises `ufunc 'isnan' not supported for the input types` at `validate_inputs` if nullable types are used for y_predicted

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
This was first discovered in [this commit](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/3895/commits/cb4e1ee866d40dd5cebe274904cfd50880d1193b), which forced nullable type usage into AutoMLSearch. It can be reproduced if nullable types are passed directly into the Objective class: 

```python
    import woodwork as ww
    from evalml.objectives import get_core_objectives 
    _, y = X_y_binary
    y_nullable = ww.init_series(y, logical_type="IntegerNullable")

    binary_objectives = get_core_objectives("binary")
    first_obj = binary_objectives[0]

    first_obj.validate_inputs(y, y_nullable)
```

IT only occurs with `y_predicted` because the `np.isnan` call for y_pred happens after the call to `y_predicted.to_numpy()`, which results in an `object` dtype when nullable types are used, resulting in the error at `isnan`. The fact that the dtype becomes `object` seems to be expected from this passage at pandas' [docs](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.24.0rc1/api/generated/pandas.Series.to_numpy.html):

> For extension types, to_numpy() may require copying data and coercing the result to a NumPy type (possibly object), which may be expensive. 


This will not currently be seen in automl search because of the replace nullable types component, but we should consider adding nullable handling into the Objective class itself so that it can independently support nullable types.

title: DFS Transformer can produce incorrect results in partial dependence fast mode if engineered features are present

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
The intent of passing `features` into the DFS transformer is that it allows us to avoid calling calculate feature matrix on `X` if we've already calculated the feature values for the inputted list of features. For partial dependence fast mode, we only allow pipelines that contain the DFS Transformer when this is the case (See for explanation why [here](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/tests/model_understanding_tests/test_partial_dependence.py#L2657-L2660)). 

The logic that determines whether or not calculate feature matrix is called cannot properly account for fast mode refitting a cloned pipeline on a single column, so if the single column had a feature engineered from it, we will attempt to calculate feature values for it, which does not match the behavior of slow mode.

Because of https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/3872, this will currently raise errors when the features were not trained on a dataframe named `"X"`.  Once that is fixed, though, we can still see that the partial dependence values for fast mode in these cases are different from slow mode.

We should update `DFSTransformer._handle_partial_dependence_fast_mode` to update the `features` parameter such that we do not run `calcualte_feature_matrix` when we transform the single column pipeline. One way to do this is to set features to be an empty list, but that will require changing how we set `_passed_in_features`, which just looks at the truthy value of features.

title: DFS Transformer will error if features passed in have DataFrame name that is not "X"

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
In the dfs transformer, we create an entity set with a dataframe named `X`. In the cases where users pass in their own `features`, we may end up running `calculate_feature_matrix` using those features and the entityset created by the DFS Transformer. In that situation, if the features were not created from a DataFrame named `X`, we get an error in Featuretools that `DataFrame <different name> does not exist in entity set` at transform.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
    X, y = X_y_binary
    X_pd = pd.DataFrame(X)
    X_pd.columns = X_pd.columns.astype(str)

    es = ft.EntitySet()
    es = es.add_dataframe(
        dataframe_name="Xdiff",
        dataframe=X_pd,
        index="index",
        make_index=True,
    )
    feature_matrix, features = ft.dfs(
        entityset=es,
        target_dataframe_name="Xdiff",
        trans_primitives=["absolute"],
    )

    dfs = DFSTransformer(features=features)
    dfs.fit(X_pd)  # no-op
    X_t = dfs.transform(X_pd)
```
If this is a requirement, we should make that clear in the documentation, but if the name of the dataframe in the entityset being `"X"` is not a requirement, we should just set the name to be the same as the dataframe used to create the features, if features are passed in at init. We can do this by looking at `self.features[0].dataframe_name`.

body: Currently our time series native estimators. such as ARIMA, do not respect the `should_drop_time_index`  flag and goes through the logic of adding null rows for the gap for time series featurization. This was fixed in #3849 but was reverted due to an outstanding bug.

title: Partial dependence fast mode may fail Random Forest pipelines if there are more than 10 categories that are one-hot encoded

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
If The Random Forest Feature Selector is used in a pipeline where there are categorical columns containing more than 10 (or whatever top_n is set to) categories, only the top n categories for that categorical column will be one-hot encoded. In partial dependence fast mode, the top n for the column whose partial dependence we're calculating will be different, because we've updated the values to all be one grid value, so different columns will be considered the "top n".

This may produce slightly different partial dependence values, and also can cause an error if the Random Forest Feature Selector is used and the original transformed X has columns that the resulting single-column-transformed dataframe doesn't have.

To avoid this, we should implement `_handle_partial_dependence_fast_mode` for the OneHotEncoder and set `top_n` to be as large as the number of categories in the column in X with the most categories (plus one to account for nans?).

title: Partial Dependence loses `origin` property on Engineered Features

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
When the DFS transformer is present in a pipeline, we remove any engineered features from `X_test` when transforming the pipeline so that we can check the types of X_test as they compare to the original data the pipeline was fit on. We do this by checking the `series.ww.origin` attribute via woodwork to see if the origin is `'engineered'`.

In partial dependence, though, we [replace columns](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/model_understanding/_partial_dependence_utils.py#L318-L321) in `X_test` 
with series' that have updated values, and we do not pass along the `origin` value. This means that when we calculate partial dependence for engineered features, they have an origin of `None`, which will be [treated as a base feature](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py#L413-L419). This eventually results in an error that `Input X data types are different from the input types the pipeline was fitted on.`.

To avoid this error, we should pass along the origin value when initializing woodwork on the updated series.

title: Partial Dependence Fast Mode will fail if DFS Transformer is used and multi-output primitive was used

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
The DFSTransformer component checks that all features are present in X in `_handle_partial_dependence_fast_mode` by looking at `f.get_name()` for all the features in the `features` parameter. This will cause it to raise the value error that not all features are present in X, because the features in X will be the features you get with `f.get_feature_names()` in order to 

This can be fixed by using `feature.get_feature_names()` instead and comparing the names in those lists to X.

```python
from evalml.pipelines.components.transformers.preprocessing.stl_decomposer import STLDecomposer
```

title: TimeSeriesFeaturizer doesn't appear to use correct significant lags in most cases

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
The lagged features that get generated by the `TimeSeriesFeaturizer` do not use the significant lags found by `_find_significant_lags` in most cases. Changing the forecast horizon and/or the gap parameters change the lagged features that are created, but these parameters are not directly used when identifying which lags are significant, only the max_delay is used.

The current process is something like this, if I am following the code correctly:
- Find all significant lags in the range of (0, max_delay)
- Add the start delay (which is gap + forecast_horizon) to the lags found from the previous step

This means that the significant lags that were identified can be offset, making them insignificant.

I believe the proper approach should be more like this:
- Use the gap and forecast_horizon and max_delay to identify the rows that fall within the feature engineering window
- Identify significant lags that fall within the feature engineering window
- Create lagged features from those significant lags without further modification

The problem is illustrated in the example below. Changing the forecast horizon changes the lagged features that are created.

**Forecast Horizon of 1**

```python
import pandas as pd
import featuretools as ft

from evalml.pipelines import TimeSeriesRegressionPipeline

df = pd.read_csv("DailyDelhiClimateTrain.csv", nrows=200)

max_delay = 10
gap = 0
forecast_horizon = 1

component_graph_as_list = ["Time Series Featurizer"]
parameters = {
    "pipeline": {
        "time_index": "date",
        "gap": gap,
        "max_delay": max_delay,
        "forecast_horizon": forecast_horizon,
    },
    "Time Series Featurizer": {
        "time_index": "date",
        "gap": gap,
        "max_delay": max_delay,
        "forecast_horizon": forecast_horizon,
    }
}
pipeline = TimeSeriesRegressionPipeline(component_graph=component_graph_as_list, parameters=parameters)

y = df.pop("meantemp")
X = df[["date"]]

p = pipeline.fit(X, y)

# For simplicity assume the first and fourth lags were found to be significant (zero indexed)
p.component_graph["Time Series Featurizer"].statistically_significant_lags = [0, 3]

p.transform(X, y).head()
```

For this first case, we create target delay features of 1 period and 4 periods as we expect
```
        date  target_delay_1  target_delay_4  target_rolling_mean
0 2013-01-01             NaN             NaN                  NaN
1 2013-01-02       10.000000             NaN                  NaN
2 2013-01-03        7.400000             NaN                  NaN
3 2013-01-04        7.166667             NaN             8.188889
4 2013-01-05        8.666667            10.0             7.744444
```

If we change nothing but making `forecast_horizon = 2` and run this again, we get a different result. We now create delay features of 2 period and 5 periods, neither of which were identified as significant. It seems to me that changing the number of points we want to forecast in the future should have no bearing on which lag features are created, only on which lags we can use.

For this case, we could not use the lag of 1 feature, because we would have no data available for the second forecast point (the feature engineering window doesn't include the previous row in this case). We should still be able to use the lag of 4 feature, which was significant.

**Forecast Horizon of 2**
```
        date  target_delay_2  target_delay_5  target_rolling_mean
0 2013-01-01             NaN             NaN                  NaN
1 2013-01-02             NaN             NaN                  NaN
2 2013-01-03       10.000000             NaN                  NaN
3 2013-01-04        7.400000             NaN                  NaN
4 2013-01-05        7.166667             NaN             8.188889
```

title: AutoMLSearch fails if target column is IntegerNullable logical type

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Running `automl.search()` fails when the target column is an `IntegerNullable` logical type.  This was discovered on a time series regression problem, but have not tested to see if this same error happens for other problem types. This should also be checked.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
import pandas as pd
from evalml import AutoMLSearch

df = pd.read_csv("bike_sharing_demand_train_cleaned.csv", nrows=500)
df.ww.init(logical_types={"datetime": "Datetime", "count": "IntegerNullable"})

y = df.ww.pop("count")
X = df

problem_configuration={"gap": 0, "max_delay": 7, "forecast_horizon": 7, "time_index": "datetime"}
automl = AutoMLSearch(
    X,
    y,
    problem_type="time series regression",
    problem_configuration=problem_configuration,
)

automl.search()
```

Error on L386 of `pipeline_base.py` `_score_all_objectives` method:

```
Fold 0: Exception during automl search: Root Mean Squared Error encountered TypeError with message (loop of ufunc does not support argument 0 of type float which has no callable sqrt method):
```

title: AutoMLSearch fails with Ordinal logical type input from Featuretools

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
AutoMLSearch fails if the input contains Ordinal data from Featuretools, such as that generated by the `Year`, `Month`, etc primitives.

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
import featuretools as ft
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("delhi_200.csv")

es = ft.EntitySet()
es.add_dataframe(dataframe_name="df", dataframe=df, index="id", make_index=True, time_index="date")
es["df"].ww

trans_primitives = ["day"]
features = ft.dfs(entityset=es,
                  target_dataframe_name="df",
                  max_depth=1,
                  features_only=True,
                  trans_primitives=trans_primitives)
features.append(ft.Feature(es["df"].ww["date"]))
fm = ft.calculate_feature_matrix(entityset=es, features=features)
y = fm.ww.pop("meantemp")
X = fm

problem_configuration={"gap": 0, "max_delay": 7, "forecast_horizon": 7, "time_index": "date"}
automl = AutoMLSearch(
    X,
    y,
    problem_type="time series regression",
    problem_configuration=problem_configuration,
)

automl.search()

```


title: Enhance Decomposer() with .get_seasonal_periodicty()

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: An improvement to an existing feature.

labels.name: new feature
labels.description: Features which don't yet exist.

body:
Currently, the `PolynomialDecomposer` calls `freq_to_period` based on the time series frequency string stored in the `DateTimeIndex` of the target variable.  This returns a periodicity integer which may not always reflect the actual periodicity of the signal.  

For instance, if the target data has daily data, meaning each entry corresponds to a different day, then the `freq_to_period` function will return a periodicity of 7.  When this gets passed into the `seasonal_decompose`, the result is that the moving average seasonality assumes that the seasonal component of the signal repeats every 7 values.  If this is the case, then the function decomposes correctly.  If not, then the decomposition is weird and wrong.

We can correct this in two steps:

1. Make PolynomialDecomposer accept an integer period, reflecting that the user has identified the period manually.  Then pass this value in and use it.  
2. Make the PolynomialDecomposer intelligently determine the period of the seasonal signal.

title: Time series modeling does not work properly when datetime and time series featurizers are disabled.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
With `DatetimeFeaturizer` and `TimeSeries` featurizers disabled, several errors are encountered during model search. I would expect the example below to work without errors.

High-level steps needed to resolve this:
- Baseline pipelines need to be updated to run without the presences of a `TimeSeriesFeaturizer` component
- Logic needs to properly handle passing the time index column to models that need it (ARIMA, Prophet), but not to the "classical" models that cannot operate with a datetime column present
- Code interactions between `TimeSeriesPipelineBase` and `TimeSeriesFeaturizer` need to be resolved so that the absence of a `TimeSeriesFeaturizer` does not cause errors

@jeremyliweishih @ParthivNaresh Feel free to update this based on any additional investigations you perform.

#### Code Sample

```python
import featuretools as ft
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("DailyDelhiClimateTrain.csv")

es = ft.EntitySet()
es.add_dataframe(dataframe_name="df", dataframe=df, index="id", make_index=True)

features = ft.dfs(entityset=es, target_dataframe_name="df", max_depth=1, features_only=True)
features.append(ft.Feature(es["df"].ww["date"]))
fm = ft.calculate_feature_matrix(entityset=es, features=features)
y = fm.ww.pop("meantemp")
X = fm

automl = AutoMLSearch(
    X,
    y,
    problem_type="time series regression",
    problem_configuration={"gap": 0, "max_delay": 7, "forecast_horizon": 7, "time_index": "date"},
    exclude_featurizers=["DatetimeFeaturizer", "TimeSeriesFeaturizer"]
)
automl.search()
```
[DailyDelhiClimateTrain.csv](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/files/9339155/DailyDelhiClimateTrain.csv)

The problem is that I split the datasets and run the analysis, I get an error saying `"Input X data types are different from the input types the pipeline was fitted on."`. After looking into it, I realised `woodwork` inferred schema decides that some of the variables in the test set have a different type than the one assigned to them during the automl search and fitting. My guess is that this crashes when it classifies extra variables as `unknown` type.

title: Imputer cannot impute generated features from EmailFeaturizer if missing values are present

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
from evalml.pipelines import RegressionPipeline
from evalml.pipelines.components import EmailFeaturizer, Imputer
import pytest

X = pd.DataFrame({"email": ["me@email.com", "foo@bar.org", "baz@foo.gov", None],
                  "number": [1, 2, 3, 4]})
y = pd.Series([1, 2, 1, 3])

pl = RegressionPipeline([EmailFeaturizer, Imputer])

with pytest.raises(AttributeError, match="'bool' object has no attribute 'transpose'"):
    pl.fit(X, y)

```

This is related to the pandas 1.4.0 upgrade. Pandas 1.4.0 will create use the nullable `<NA>` type for missing values in categorical features! Before it was just numpy `NaN`.

### Pandas 1.4.0
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/157289755-4ca79819-d4e8-4677-ae39-128f66919d0c.png)

### Pandas 1.3.5
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/157289811-e5dd6b7a-3c5c-4ac8-9e2c-bc7c5e349a91.png)

title: NoVarianceDataCheck should allow the target to be optional

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
from evalml.demos import load_diabetes
from evalml.data_checks import NoVarianceDataCheck
import pytest

X, _ = load_diabetes()

with pytest.raises(AttributeError, match="'NoneType' object has no attribute 'ww'"):
    NoVarianceDataCheck().validate(X, None)
```

Calculating whether a column is "no variance" does not depend on a target variable being defined. This is a break from out DataChecks api of having a default value of `None` for the target variable.

title: AutoMLSearch uses optimal threshold of last fold in get_pipeline for binary classification

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
`AutoMLSearch.get_pipeline` will set the optimal threshold as the threshold found in the last cv fold. However, we store the optimal threshold for all cv folds. It's not clear that the threshold on the last fold is the best one or the one that should be used in "production".

#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.demos import load_fraud

X, y = load_fraud(1000)

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, "binary", verbose=True)
automl.search()

pipeline = automl.get_pipeline(1)
threshold_last_fold = automl.results['pipeline_results'][1]['cv_data'][-1]['binary_classification_threshold']

assert pipeline == threshold_last_fold
```

```python
print([i['binary_classification_threshold'] for i in automl.results['pipeline_results'][1]['cv_data']])
```

```
[0.2739189310625345, 0.3644718206383961, 0.2954551911484392]
```

title: Partial Dependence Returns all nan feature_values when input data has NaN

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example to reproduce your bug.

```python
import pandas as pd
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from evalml.model_understanding import partial_dependence

X = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, None, 3]*2,
                  "b": [4, 5, 6, 7]*2})
y = pd.Series([1, 0, 0, 1]*2)
X_holdout = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, None, 2, 3]*2,
                  "b": [4, 5, 6, 7]*2})

pipeline = BinaryClassificationPipeline(
    component_graph={'Label Encoder': ['Label Encoder', 'X', 'y'],
                     'Imputer': ['Imputer', 'X', 'Label Encoder.y'],
                     'Random Forest Classifier': ['Random Forest Classifier', 'Imputer.x', 'Label Encoder.y']})
pipeline.fit(X, y)

dep = partial_dependence(pipeline, X_holdout, "a", grid_resolution=3)
assert dep.feature_values.isna().all()
assert dep.partial_dependence.nunique() == 1
```

The problem is the grid calculation. `np.linspace` will return all NaNs if one of the values it's interpolating between is `NaN`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/149026970-618584b2-297a-4309-88de-cb8970cbbaac.png)

I recommend we filter NaNs prior to grid generation.

title: SHAP prediction explanations fail when classification predicts probability of 1

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro: run `explain_predictions_best_worst` on an estimator that predicts a class with 100% certainty for at least one data point. 

This comes from a SHAP library bug, [issue #2000](https://github.com/slundberg/shap/issues/2000). The logit link function fails because said function is infinite at 0 and 1.

title: ARIMA cannot handle boolean features

body:

```python
from evalml.demos import load_weather
from evalml.pipelines.components import ARIMARegressor
import pandas as pd
import pytest

X, y = load_weather()

X.ww['bool_1'] = pd.Series([True, False]).sample(n=X.shape[0], replace=True, random_state=0).reset_index(drop=True)
X.ww['bool_2'] = pd.Series([True, False]).sample(n=X.shape[0], replace=True, random_state=1).reset_index(drop=True)

with pytest.raises(TypeError, match="numpy boolean subtract, the `-` operator, is not supported"):

X.ww['float_1'] = pd.Series([1.2, 2.3, 3.14]).sample(n=X.shape[0], replace=True, random_state=0).reset_index(drop=True)
```

title: Optimize_threshold not working as expected

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Issues tracking performance improvements.

body:
Repro (in test file):
```python
def test_find_confusion_matrix_pipeline_threshold_tester(
    logistic_regression_binary_pipeline_class, X_y_binary
):
    bcp = logistic_regression_binary_pipeline_class({})
    X, y = X_y_binary
    y = pd.Series(y)
    bcp.fit(X, y)
    preds = bcp.predict_proba(X).iloc[:, 1]
    bcp.optimize_threshold(X, y, preds, AccuracyBinary())
    print(bcp.threshold)
    print(bcp.score(X, y, [AccuracyBinary()]))
    bcp.threshold = 0.5
    print(bcp.score(X, y, [AccuracyBinary()]))
```
Note that here, the accuracy is higher when we use a threshold of 0.5 versus the threshold we optimized with. A summary of this finding can be seen [here](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/3080). 

We see that our optimize threshold method isn't able to find this better threshold, which we can note as a performance bug. We expect that we should be able to find the 0.5 threshold as the optimal, but currently do not. This issue tracks resolving this performance discrepancy and fixing our `optimize_threshold` method.

body:

```python
from evalml.pipelines import TimeSeriesRegressionPipeline
from evalml.demos import load_weather
import pandas as pd
import pytest

X, y = load_weather()
X.ww['other_features'] = pd.Series(range(X.shape[0]))

pl = TimeSeriesRegressionPipeline(["Delayed Feature Transformer", "DateTime Featurization Component",
                                   "Elastic Net Regressor"],
                                  {"pipeline": {"gap": 0, "max_delay": 7,
                                                "forecast_horizon": 5,
                                                "date_index": "Date"},
                                   "Delayed Feature Transformer": {"gap": 0,
                                                                  "max_delay": 7,
                                                                  "forecast_horizon": 5,
                                                                   "date_index": "Date"}})

X_train, y_train = X.ww.iloc[:-5], y.ww.iloc[:-5]
X_test = X.ww.iloc[-5:]

pl.fit(X_train, y_train)

with pytest.raises(Exception, match="Error converting datatype for other_features from type float64 to type int64"):
    pl.predict(X_test.ww.drop(["other_features"]), None, X_train, y_train)
```

The problem is that in a real setting, the `other_features` will likely not be present in the data because it's not known ahead of time. Our implementation should be aware of that.

title: Preserve input indices on pipeline predict/predict_proba

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro
```python
import evalml
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
X, y = evalml.demos.load_breast_cancer()

X_train, X_holdout, y_train, y_holdout = evalml.preprocessing.split_data(X, y, problem_type='binary',
                                                                         test_size=0.2, random_seed=0)


pipeline_binary = BinaryClassificationPipeline(component_graph = {
            "Label Encoder": ["Label Encoder", "X", "y"],
            "Imputer": ["Imputer", "X", "Label Encoder.y"],
            "Random Forest Classifier": [
                "Random Forest Classifier",
                "Imputer.x",
                "Label Encoder.y",
            ],
        })
pipeline_binary.fit(X_train, y_train)
index2 = pipeline_binary.predict(X_holdout).index
assert X_holdout.index.tolist() == index2.tolist()
```

Right now, our pipelines aren't preserving the passed-in indices for both `predict/predict_proba`. This was noted for our classification pipelines, but our regression pipelines likely have the same issue with `predict`. This issue tracks fixing this such that the output indices will match the input indices.

title: Time Series Problems with Categoricals Score Nan

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: An improvement to an existing feature.

body:
Currently, if you pass a time series dataset with a categorical feature to AutoMLSearch, many of the models will score `nan`.

Repro
```python
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.demos import load_weather
import pandas as pd

X, y = load_weather()
X.ww["categorical_feature"] = pd.Series(["a", "b", "c"]).sample(X.shape[0], replace=True).reset_index(drop=True)

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, "time series regression",
                      problem_configuration={"max_delay": 5, "gap": 3, "forecast_horizon": 2,
                                             "date_index": "Date"},
                     verbose=True)
automl.search()

assert automl.rankings.mean_cv_score.isna().any()
```

This is because we currently place the `OneHotEncoder` after the `DelayedFeatureTransformer` and since the `DelayedFeatureTransformer` creates NaN in some features, the `OneHotEncoder` errors out because it cannot handle NaN.

However, I don't think simple `OneHotEncoding` prior to `DelayedFeatureTransformer` should close this issue.

I think what we should do is do is compute some or all following features:
1. Most common category seen in the past window of observations
2. How often each category comes up in the past window of observations.
3. Most common category in the previous k days

etc.

title: Which features should we pass to ARIMA?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: spike
labels.description: To generate additional issues and kick off a sprint.

body:
Currently, if the time series problem is multivariate, ARIMA will receive an exact copy of the input data to to fit on.

Reproducer,

```python
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
from unittest.mock import patch
from evalml.demos import load_weather
import pandas as pd

ARIMA_PATH = "sktime.forecasting.arima.AutoARIMA"

SIZE_OF_FIRST_SPLIT = 914

X, y = load_weather()
X.ww["other_feature"] = y - 1

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, "time series regression", verbose=True,
                      problem_configuration={"date_index": "Date",
                                             "forecast_horizon": 1,
                                             "gap": 0,
                                             "max_delay": 10})

with patch(f"{ARIMA_PATH}.fit") as mock_fit, \
    patch(f"{ARIMA_PATH}.predict", side_effect=lambda fh, X: pd.Series(range(X.shape[0]))):
    automl.search()

expected_answer = X.ww.copy()
expected_answer = X.ww.iloc[:SIZE_OF_FIRST_SPLIT, :]
expected_answer.index = pd.DatetimeIndex(expected_answer['Date'], "D")
expected_answer = expected_answer.ww.drop(["Date"])

pd.testing.assert_frame_equal(mock_fit.call_args_list[0].kwargs['X'], expected_answer)
```

I think this is problematic because the `other_feature` in this case may not be known in advanced and this could be a case of data leakage - training a model on data that would not be available at predict time.

The other pipelines receive the input features after feature-engineering, namely lagging and soon-to-be rolling windows, so the `other_feature` would not be given as-is to the pipeline. For that reason, the other pipelines do not suffer from the same problem as ARIMA.

We need to decide:

- Should we even pass features to ARIMA? Why not just pass in the target values
- If we want to pass in some features, we need to make sure there is no leakage.

Step 1 of this issue is reaching consensus on the above decision, then we can decide how to best implement that.

title: SMOTENC Oversampler fix

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
[This line](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/8357f1369f78608bc38d5424687208a2792c19ba/evalml/pipelines/components/transformers/samplers/oversampler.py#L79) in the code is likely leading to a bug where some categorical columns, when one-hot encoded, don't get caught. This is likely due to our check for `categorical` rather than both `boolean` and `categorical`. 

Found by @freddyaboulton through [this thread](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/2946#discussion_r734641996).

title: Classification Pipeline _encoder property is not set if using a custom name for encoder

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro
```python
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline

X, y = load_breast_cancer()

pl = BinaryClassificationPipeline({"LE": ["Label Encoder", "X", "y"],
                                                         "RF": ["CatBoost Classifier", "X", "LE.y"]})
pl.fit(X, y)
assert pl._encoder is None
```

This can break some of the model understanding tools that call `_encode_targets`. 

I think we need a better way of setting the `_encoder` property or maybe we need to think of a better way to support "one-off" encoding outside of pipeline fit than `_encode_targets`.

title: Drop Columns Transformer does not have columns to drop in `DefaultAlgorithm`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Work being done to refactor code.

body:
Currently, if a Drop Columns Transformer is added as part of `make_pipeline` there are no parameters/columns associated with this component. Thus, `DefaultAlgorithm` errors out when there are columns that need to be drop (namely columns of unknown type). This was found using `car-sales.csv` where the car name is an unknown type that happens to be a string and this string does not get encoded as it only looks for categorical columns (the string being an unknown type should be another issue). 

To get around this, `IterativeAlgorithm` finds the unknown columns and adds them as parameters to each pipeline. This issue tracks doing the same for `DefaultAlgorithm` or better yet: find a solution where we can add parameters to `make_pipeline` to standardize this behavior.

title: Partial dependence fails when categorical column gets typed as natural language by user

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
```python
from evalml.demos import load_fraud
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
import pytest
from evalml.model_understanding import partial_dependence
from evalml.exceptions import PartialDependenceError

X, y = load_fraud(100)
X = X.ww[["card_id", "store_id", "amount", "provider"]]
X.ww.set_types({"provider": "NaturalLanguage"})

pl = BinaryClassificationPipeline(component_graph={'Label Encoder': ['Label Encoder', 'X', 'y'],
                                                   'Text Featurization Component': ['Text Featurization Component', 'X', 'Label Encoder.y'],
                                                   'Imputer': ['Imputer', 'Text Featurization Component.x', 'Label Encoder.y'], 
                                                   'LightGBM Classifier': ['LightGBM Classifier', 'Imputer.x', 'Label Encoder.y']})
pl.fit(X, y)

X_test, y_test = load_fraud(100)
X_test = X_test.ww[["card_id", "store_id", "amount", "provider"]]
X_test["provider"][-1] = None
X_test.ww.set_types({"provider": "NaturalLanguage"})

with pytest.raises(PartialDependenceError):
    partial_dependence(pl, X_test, "card_id")
```

The error message is `ValueError: Cannot setitem on a Categorical with a new category, set the categories first`. The problem is that the `provider` feature is meant to be treatd as NaturalLanguage, however partial dependence is not respecting that and instead infers the feature as categorical. This causes `[_clean_text](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/components/transformers/preprocessing/text_featurizer.py#L51)` to error out because we're introducing a new value `" "` into a categorical feature.

title: `DefaultAlgorithm` errors out during cross validation with encoder and feature selection interaction

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Related to #2903

After running a naive pipeline with preprocessing and a random forest estimator, we use the random forest estimator to create a feature selection component. However, since the feature selection component selects columns after the encoder, these columns are post-encoding columns. In the scenario where different values are provided to the encoder during validation, the encoder may not provide the columns selected by the feature selector and the feature selector will error out since it cannot find the same columns. For example below, an original column would be `INTERNODE_21` but post-encoding these columns would become `INTERNODE_21_X`. title: `DefaultAlgorithm` errors out with `CatBoost` pipelines

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
After running a naive pipeline with preprocessing and a random forest estimator, we use the random forest estimator to create a feature selection component. However, since the feature selection component selects columns after the encoder,  these columns are post-encoding columns. In the scenario where a `CatBoost` estimator is used, `make_pipelines` does not add a one hot encoder and thus does not provide encoded columns to the feature selector and the feature selector will error out since it cannot find the same columns.

title: `calculate_permutation_importance` loses ww type

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro:
```
import pytest
import woodwork as ww

from evalml.demos import load_fraud
from evalml.model_understanding import calculate_permutation_importance
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline

X, y = load_fraud(n_rows=1000)
X.ww.init()
y.ww.init()

component_graph = [
    "Imputer",
    "One Hot Encoder",
    "Standard Scaler",
    "Logistic Regression Classifier",
]
pipeline = BinaryClassificationPipeline(component_graph)
pipeline.fit(X, y)

with pytest.raises(WoodworkNotInitError):
    calculate_permutation_importance(pipeline, X, y, objective='log loss binary')
```

Associated Warning:
```
  Operation performed by select_dtypes has invalidated the Woodwork typing information:
   The following columns in the typing information were missing from the DataFrame: {'datetime'}.
   Please initialize Woodwork with DataFrame.ww.init
```
`select_dtypes` is called in the `StandardScaler`.

title: AutoMLSearch does not respect the desired estimator family order

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.model_family import ModelFamily

X, y = load_breast_cancer()
automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, "binary", max_iterations=5)
automl.search()
searched_model_families = [
        automl.get_pipeline(search_index).estimator.model_family
        for search_index in automl.results["search_order"][1:]
    ]
assert searched_model_families != [ModelFamily.LINEAR_MODEL, ModelFamily.LINEAR_MODEL,
                                                             ModelFamily.DECISION_TREE, ModelFamily.EXTRA_TREES]
```

title: Best pipeline trained by AutoMLSearch gets different score than cloned version trained on `X_train`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro:
```

# dataset and modification comes from vowpal wabbit example
import numpy as np
from sklearn import datasets
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
X, y = datasets.make_hastie_10_2(n_samples=15000, random_state=1)
X = X.astype(np.float32)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, random_state=256)

automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(X_train=X_train, y_train=y_train, 
                                    problem_type='binary', verbose=True, max_batches=3,
                                    train_best_pipeline=True)
automl.search()
automl.best_pipeline.score(X_test, y_test, objectives=['Accuracy Binary'])
```

This score (0.933) is different from:
```
clone = automl.best_pipeline.clone()
clone.fit(X_train, y_train)
clone.score(X_test, y_test, objectives=['Accuracy Binary'])
```

This feels like a bug to me. If we set `train_best_pipeline` to `False` and then `fit` on `X_train`, and `y_train`, we get the same result as the clone:
```
automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(X_train=X_train, y_train=y_train, 
                                    problem_type='binary', verbose=True, max_batches=3,
                                    train_best_pipeline=False)
automl.search()
automl.best_pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)
automl.best_pipeline.score(X_test, y_test, objectives=['Accuracy Binary'])
```

Is it possible that the data we're using to train the best pipeline is not the whole X_train/y_train? Or some data transformation is happening?

title: AutoMLSearch.score_pipelines does not work for time series pipelines

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro
```python
from evalml.demos import load_weather
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
import numpy as np

X, y = load_weather()

train_dates, test_dates = X.Date < "1990-01-01", X.Date >= "1990-01-01"
X_train, y_train = X.ww.loc[train_dates], y.ww.loc[train_dates]
X_test, y_test =  X.ww.loc[test_dates], y.ww.loc[test_dates]

automl = AutoMLSearch(X_train, y_train, problem_type="time series regression",
                      max_iterations=5,
                      problem_configuration={"gap": 0, "max_delay": 7,
                                             "forecast_horizon": 7, "date_index": None},
                      allowed_model_families=["xgboost", "random_forest", "linear_model", "extra_trees",
                                              "decision_tree"],
                      verbose=False)

automl.search()
pl = automl.best_pipeline
pl.fit(X_train, y_train)

scores = automl.score_pipelines([pl], X_test, y_test, ["MedianAE"])
assert np.isnan(scores[pl.name]["MedianAE"])
```

We need to pass `X_train` and `y_train` as optional arguments to the api of `score_pipeline`:

https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/engine/engine_base.py#L329

title: Imputer.transform erases woodwork typing information

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
from evalml.pipelines.components import Imputer
import pytest

df_train = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, 3, 2], "b": ["a", "b", "b", "c"]})
df_holdout = pd.DataFrame({"a": [2], "b": [None]})
df_train.ww.init(logical_types={"a": "Double", "b": "Categorical"})
df_holdout.ww.init(logical_types={"a": "Double", "b": "Categorical"})

imputer = Imputer()
imputer.fit(df_train, None)

with pytest.raises(ValueError, match="could not convert string to float: 'b'"):
    imputer.transform(df_holdout, None)
```

The problem is that the imputer selects the categorical columns but it does not go through the ww accessor to do so. This means that the `SimpleImputer` used for categoricals has to do type inference. Since `b` is all Nulls, the inferred type is `Unknown`, which causes `infer_feature_types` to convert it to a double logical type. 

If the imputer selected the categorical columns through the ww accessor, the `SimpleImputer` would not infer `b` as `Unknown` so we would not try to convert `b` to `Double`.

```
}

cg_with_estimators.describe()
```

```
<ipython-input-5-3005b62da7ab> in <module>

---> 16 cg_with_estimators.describe()

~/Desktop/evalml/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py in describe(self, return_dict)
```

title: `partial_dependence` with ensembles errors

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Currently, trying to run `partial_dependence` with a stacked ensemble pipeline will raise the following error:

```

PartialDependenceError                    Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-12-4f356ba3e6ad> in <module>
      3     partial_dependence,
      4 )
----> 5 graph_partial_dependence(ensemble, X, 'Sex')

~/Desktop/evalml/evalml/model_understanding/graphs.py in graph_partial_dependence(pipeline, X, features, class_label, grid_resolution, kind)
    996 
    997     part_dep = partial_dependence(
--> 998         pipeline, X, features=features, grid_resolution=grid_resolution, kind=kind
    999     )
   1000 

~/Desktop/evalml/evalml/model_understanding/graphs.py in partial_dependence(pipeline, X, features, percentiles, grid_resolution, kind)
    856             raise PartialDependenceError(
    857                 str(e), PartialDependenceErrorCode.ALL_OTHER_ERRORS
--> 858             ) from e
    859 
    860 

PartialDependenceError: feature_importance is not implemented for SklearnStackedEnsembleClassifier and SklearnStackedEnsembleRegressor

```

This is because our ensemble estimator wraps a scikit-learn estimator using `scikit_learn_wrapped_estimator`. Within our wrapper classes, we call:
```
        if pipeline._is_fitted:
            self.feature_importances_ = pipeline.feature_importance
            self._is_fitted = True
            self.classes_ = pipeline.classes_
```

For a fitted ensemble, calling `self.feature_importances_ = pipeline.feature_importance` will error out since our ensemble does not support feature_importance (calling ensemble_pipeline.feature_importance throws an error).

As a fix, we should not try to set this attribute for ensemble components! Instead, however, we will need another attribute that ends with an underscore, such as attribute_; this is because partial dependence can only be calculated on fitted components, and scikit-learn considers a component that ends in a underscore as a fitted component.


This issue tracks adding a test for calculating partial dependence with ensembles and resolving this bug :)

title: Have fit_features return the transformed target

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
This came up during #2697

Our time series pipelines rely on `compute_estimator_features` to transform the data, then do some custom-time-series specific data transformations before passing the data to the estimator. 

Excerpt from our [time series regression pipeline](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/time_series_regression_pipeline.py#L45):

```python
        X, y = self._convert_to_woodwork(X, y)
        features = self.compute_estimator_features(X, y)
        features_no_nan, y = drop_rows_with_nans(features, y)
        predictions = self._estimator_predict(features_no_nan, y)
```

This means that the detrender is not working as expected for time series regression pipelines.

This touches more than just time series pipelines. We use `compute_estimator_features` in our `permutation_importance` optimization [algorithm](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/model_understanding/permutation_importance.py#L37). 

This means that the estimator is outputting transformed predictions but it's being compared against the untransformed target variable in [scoring](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/model_understanding/permutation_importance.py#L313). This means our permutation importance algorithm is not accurate for pipelines with target transformers (not including over/undersamplers)

title: TargetLeakageDataCheck wipes user-selected logical types

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
from evalml.data_checks import TargetLeakageDataCheck

X = pd.DataFrame({"A": pd.Series([1, 2, 3]),
                  "B": pd.Series([4, 5, 6])})
y = pd.Series([1, 2, 3])

X.ww.init(logical_types={"A": "Unknown", "B": "Double"})

assert any(w['message'].startswith("Column 'A'") for w in TargetLeakageDataCheck().validate(X, y)['warnings'])
```

Woodwork only allows mutual information on numeric, categorical, boolean, and datetime features so if the `TargetLeakageDataCheck` were preserving the typing information set by the user, the mutual information for column A should not be calculated!

The issue is that in the `TargetLeakageDataCheck`, we create a dataframe [without going through the ww accessor](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/data_checks/target_leakage_data_check.py#L57), so this wipes the logical types by mistake.

title: AutoMLSearch raises AttributeError when TargetDistributionDataCheck issues UserWarning and only one estimator family is allowed

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
import pandas as pd
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
import woodwork as ww
from evalml.preprocessing import split_data
import pytest

X = pd.read_csv("/Users/freddy.boulton/sources/tempo2-server/testData/stones_encoded.csv")
y = X.pop("total_sales_price")
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = split_data(X, y, "regression")

with pytest.raises(AttributeError, match="'UserWarning' object has no attribute 'components'"):
    automl = AutoMLSearch(X_train, y_train, "regression", allowed_model_families=["xgboost"],
                      max_batches=3)
```

The problem is that the `TargetDistributionDataCheck` (called during make_pipeline) is issuing a UserWarning about the p-value. This then gets caught by our [warnings filter](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_search.py#L543) and then `_catch_warnings` tries to access the `components` attribute of the warning (which doesn't exist because it's not a ParameterNotUsedWarning). 

We need to improve `_catch_warnings` to only look at `ParameterNotUsedWarnings`.

title: Logic for selecting oversampler class does not take into account data transformations that happen in pipeline

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
AutoMLSearch selects the appropriate oversampler based on the logic encapsulated in `get_best_sampler`. This logic is based on the logical types in the feature matrix. The right choice depends on whether the data is all numeric (`SMOTE`), all categorical (`SMOTEN`), or a mixture of both (`SMOTENC`).

 @eccabay and I were discussing this and we think this can cause problems because `get_best_sampler` for data is unaware of what the data will look like by the time it reaches the sampler.

This is a (admittedly contrived) repro but I think it highlights the problem. In short, when `get_best_sampler` is called, there are both categorical and numeric features so `SMOTENC` is chosen. However, the pipeline drops the categorical feature before the sampler, so `SMOTENC` errors out because it's expecting a categorical column!

```python
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.automl.utils import get_best_sampler_for_data
import pandas as pd
from evalml.automl.callbacks import raise_error_callback
import pytest

X = pd.DataFrame({"a": ["a"] * 50 + ["b"] * 25 + ["c"] * 25,
                  "b": list(range(100))})
y = pd.Series([1] * 90 + [0] * 10)
X.ww.init(logical_types={"a": "Categorical"})

sampler = get_best_sampler_for_data(X, y, sampler_method="Oversampler",
                                    sampler_balanced_ratio=0.5)

allowed_component_graph = {"DropCols": ["Drop Columns Transformer", "X", "y"],
                           "Oversampler": [sampler, "DropCols.x", "y"],
                           "RF": ["Random Forest Classifier", "Oversampler.x", "Oversampler.y"]
                            }

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, "binary", allowed_component_graphs={"pipeline": allowed_component_graph},
                      pipeline_parameters={"DropCols": {"columns": ["a"]}},
                      error_callback=raise_error_callback)
with pytest.raises(IndexError, match="arrays used as indices must be of integer \\(or boolean\\) type"):
    automl.search()
```

The stacktrace reaches `imblearn`:
```
  File "/Users/freddy.boulton/opt/miniconda3/envs/evalml/lib/python3.8/site-packages/imblearn/over_sampling/_smote/base.py", line 490, in _fit_resample
    X_categorical = X[:, self.categorical_features_]
```

I should mention that @eccabay and I started talking about this because the same problem caused a similar bug where the feature matrix contained only boolean and categorical features so this problem doesn't just arise in contrived examples.

I think an approach worth considering is to have one oversampler (as opposed to three) and then this sampler can delegate to the right kind of SMOTE based on the data passed to `fit`. This minimizes the "distance" between when the SMOTE sampler is selected and when the sampling will actually happen.

It seems that this is not a product of the LogTransformer, but is a symptom of the LinearRegressor generating extremely large positive and negative predictions on certain rows.  

Here's a snippet of the regress.csv that generated large positive predictions: 
[hail_mary.csv](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/files/6934528/hail_mary.csv)

title: Flaky test_cancel_job for process pool CFEngine

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to testing.

body:
`test_cancel_job` in `test_cf_engine.py` has flaked twice in the nightlies recently.

https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/runs/3179257203?check_suite_focus=true

https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/runs/3212514044?check_suite_focus=true

This is the stack trace:

```
    @pytest.mark.parametrize("pool_type", ["threads", "processes"])
    def test_cancel_job(X_y_binary_cls, pool_type, thread_pool, process_pool):
        """Test that training a single pipeline using the parallel engine produces the
        same results as simply running the train_pipeline function."""
        X, y = X_y_binary_cls
        pool = get_pool(pool_type, thread_pool, process_pool)
    
        with CFClient(pool) as client:
            engine = CFEngine(client=client)
            pipeline = DaskPipelineSlow({"Logistic Regression Classifier": {"n_jobs": 1}})
    
            # Verify that engine fits a pipeline
            pipeline_future = engine.submit_training_job(
                X=X, y=y, automl_config=automl_data, pipeline=pipeline
            )
            pipeline_future.cancel()
>           assert pipeline_future.is_cancelled
E           assert False
E            +  where False = <evalml.automl.engine.cf_engine.CFComputation object at 0x7fa66c368610>.is_cancelled
```

title: Support for missing data in Natural Language types

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
As of the pandas 1.3.0 upgrade, when we cast columns to Natural language type, the imputer fails. This is due to pandas changing the `NaN` value to `<NA>` instead (pd.NA), which fails on the imputer when finding the mask of missing values.
repro:
```python
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
import numpy as np
from evalml import AutoMLSearch

X = pd.DataFrame({"a": [np.nan] + [i for i in range(99)],
                  "b": [np.nan] + [f"string {i} is valid" for i in range(99)]})
X.ww.init(logical_types={"b": "NaturalLanguage"})
y = pd.Series([0] * 25 + [1] * 75)

automl = AutoMLSearch(X_train=X, y_train=y, problem_type='binary')
automl.search()
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22552445/125702386-9ff8b1f7-476e-409b-a434-e27fefa4dbb7.png)

This issue tracks fixing this so that missing values are once again supported

title: Fix Fraud Objective

body: Currently, the fraud objective has the same behavior to a variety of different inputs, as seen [here](https://alteryx.quip.com/9dUYAdLfZwCa/Fraud-and-Lead-scoring-analysis#KPcACABcR1k). title: Prediction explanations cannot be written to json when target is of type bool

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.model_understanding import explain_predictions_best_worst
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from evalml.demos import load_fraud
import json
import pytest

pipeline = BinaryClassificationPipeline(["Text Featurization Component", "DateTime Featurization Component",
                                         "One Hot Encoder", "CatBoost Classifier"])
X, y = load_fraud(1000)
pipeline.fit(X, y)

report = explain_predictions_best_worst(pipeline, X, y, output_format="dict")

with pytest.raises(TypeError, match="keys must be str, int, float, bool or None, not numpy.bool_"):
    json.dumps(report)
```

The issue here is that the column names for the predicted probabilities dataframe when the target is boolean changed from base python bools to numpy bool_ dtype.

On the left is main and on the left is 0.24.2:

![column_dtypes](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/121538965-389c9380-c9d3-11eb-98cd-638fe3b9dcf5.png)

This is the [line](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/classification_pipeline.py#L107) that is causing this change.

I think there are two fixes here:

1. Update `predict_proba` to not have `np.bool_` types in the column names
2. Apply `_make_json_serializable` to the keys of the probabilities dictionary in the explain predictions module. Probably [here](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/model_understanding/prediction_explanations/_user_interface.py#L63)

title: Fix Fraud Objective

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Through [experimenting](https://alteryx.quip.com/9dUYAdLfZwCa/Fraud-and-Lead-scoring-analysis#KPcACABcR1k) with the fraud objective, in relation to [this issue](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/2145), we found that the fraud objective will choose a 0 threshold, or always opt for a naive estimator, in order to obtain the best results in fraud. 

This issue tracks changing the fraud objective such that it no longer chooses a simple naive estimator as the best estimator.

title: Bin class: if automl objective is AUC/logloss, additional objective scores are low

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

milestone.title: One Week Sprint
milestone.description: Catch up sprint to get N'Sync with other teams.

body:
If a user passes in a secondary objective that allows for thresholding, we should threshold using this objective, even if the primary objective doesn't use it. For instance, if a user uses 'log loss binary' as the primary, and 'binary accuracy` as an additional objective, we want to score on the secondary objective using thresholded pipelines.

This is part of the issue with the lead-scoring demo, as @dsherry mentioned [here](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/2145#issuecomment-846266275)

title: Converting Datetime to Natural Language produces TextFeaturizer error during pipeline fit

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Reproducer**
```python
import evalml
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
import pytest

df = pd.read_csv('/Users/dylan.sherry/Downloads/fraud_detection_cleaned_v2_2500rows.csv')
dt = ww.DataTable(df)
y = dt.pop('fraud')
assert str(dt.logical_types['datetime']) == 'Datetime'

# manually change datetime to natural language. strange thing to do but it is possible.
dt = dt.set_types(logical_types={'datetime': 'NaturalLanguage'})
assert str(dt.logical_types['datetime']) == 'NaturalLanguage'

# define a pipeline _without_ a datetime featurizer, since there's no datetime-typed features in the data
pipeline = evalml.pipelines.BinaryClassificationPipeline([
    'Imputer', 'One Hot Encoder', 'Text Featurization Component', 'Elastic Net Classifier'])

# get error during pipeline fit
with pytest.raises(TypeError, match='invalid type promotion'):
    pipeline.fit(dt, y)
```

**Root Cause**
In our `TextFeaturizer`, we normalize to woodwork DataTable, get a pandas dataframe, run featuretools to compute some features, then run our LSA component to produce more features.

When we run the LSA component, we should be passing along the woodwork DataTable, because that contains the information that the "datetime" column happens to be NaturalLanguage-typed. However, instead we currently pass the pandas dataframe. This means the LSA component will run woodwork type inference, determine that "datetime" is a Datetime-typed feature, try to use that feature to generate TF-IDF features and error out.

[Here's the line](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/components/transformers/preprocessing/text_featurizer.py#L122) which causes the problem.

**Fix**
Short-term: update that line to provide the woodwork DataTable instead of the pandas dataframe, to preserve the user-specified feature types.
Long-term: hey @freddyaboulton does your woodwork accessor feature branch fix this problem? If not, we should definitely make a fix on there as well.
