automl.search()
```

This is potentially relevant: https://github.com/nltk/nltk/issues/1576

title: Prediction explanations fail for catboost on titanic/fraud dataset

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro for fraud dataset because it's included in evalml but the same error happens for titanic:

```python
from evalml.demos import load_fraud
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from evalml.model_understanding import explain_predictions_best_worst
import pytest

X, y = load_fraud(1000)

catboost = BinaryClassificationPipeline(["Imputer", "DateTime Featurization Component", 
                                         "Text Featurization Component", "CatBoost Classifier"])
catboost.fit(X, y)
with pytest.raises(TypeError, match="Cannot convert IntegerArray to numpy.ndarray"):
    explain_predictions_best_worst(catboost, X, y)
```

The problem is that there are pandas-`Int64` typed features in the dataframe and we [do not convert these features](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/model_understanding/prediction_explanations/_algorithms.py#L57) to numpy `int64` for catboost pipelines. That is an oversight on our part but I've tested the same code on my feature branch for the woodwork update and we no longer see the error. 

So this will be fixed by https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/2181

title: AutoML search: start_iteration_callback is passed pipeline class instead of pipeline instance

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Left over from the epic pipeline API update in #2091.
 
I think we just need to change this to provide `pipeline` as the first arg to the callback instead of `pipeline.__class__`. This is because our pipeline classes no longer contain the component graph! The pipeline instance holds this now.

https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_search.py#L461

Thanks @ColinRTaylor for sharing this with us.

title: SHAP test fails with the Elastic Net Classifier estimator

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
In [this PR](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/2269), we change the init params for ENC in order to pass the shap tests (test_shap) in the `test_algoritthms.py` file. Leaving the init params as `alpha = 0.0001` and `l1_ratio=0.15` caused a `ZeroDivisionError` while calculating shap, which is likely linked to [this](https://github.com/slundberg/shap/issues/183). 

Filing this issue to determine why the test fails and figure out a good way to avoid this error.

title: ComponentGraph appends target to final_component_features if there is a component that returns both X and y

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro


```python
from evalml.pipelines import ComponentGraph
from evalml.demos import load_fraud
cg = ComponentGraph({"Imputer": ["Imputer"],
                     "DateTime": ["DateTime Featurization Component", "Imputer.x"],
                     "OneHot": ["One Hot Encoder", "DateTime.x"],
                     "TargetImputer": ["Target Imputer", "OneHot.x", "OneHot.y"],
                     "Logistic": ["Logistic Regression Classifier", "TargetImputer.x", "TargetImputer.y"]})
cg.instantiate({})
X, y = load_fraud(1000)
cg.fit(X, y)
final_features = cg.compute_final_component_features(X, y)
assert 'TargetImputer.y' in final_features.columns
```

The `TargetImputer.y` is not a "feature" of the final estimator so I would not expect it to show up in the dataframe. This is where we transform [DataColumns](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py#L240) to dataframes so we can concat along the other parent inputs. I think we need this for when we have non-linear pipelines with multiple estimators and we want to concat the predictions before passing to a final estimator (e.g. stacked ensemble). 

I think what we should do is only iterate over the parents that end with `.x` as opposed to both `.x` and `.y`

title: PipelineBase.compute_estimator_features fails for Undersampler

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: blocker
labels.description: An issue blocking a release.

body:
**Background**
Our `ComponentGraph` (first added in Dec 2020) was not originally intended to support transformer components which can alter the supervised target data.

The undersampler was recently added as a component in the graph (#2030 ). The undersampler component is the first component we've had which alters the target data. The way the undersampler currently works is:
* First we assume that in the `ComponentGraph`, each transformers' `fit_transform` is called only during fit, whereas `transform` is called during predict.
* Define undersampler `fit_transform` to apply undersampling to the input data and target at the same time.
* Define undersampler `transform` to be a no-op, and to pass both X and y through from input to output, because we assume this only happens at pipeline `predict`-time.

When we added the undersampler in #2030 and related PRs, we added test coverage for evaluating the component, and for using the component in a pipeline and calling pipeline `fit`/`predict`. That all works just great. What we didn't add coverage for is for calling the method `PipelineBase.compute_estimator_features` on a pipeline with the undersampler in it! This is used by permutation importance, which is how we first noticed the bug.

**Symptoms**
Calling `PipelineBase.compute_estimator_features` on a pipeline which uses the undersampler results in a stack trace. Reproducer at the bottom.

**Cause**
Because undersampler `transform` returns both X and y, our current `ComponentGraph` impl [will save the unmodified target returned from that method under the key `"Undersampler.y"`](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py#L242) in the component features dict during evaluation. This doesn't cause problems during pipeline fit and predict, but when features are computed for each transformer [in `_fit_transform_features_helper`,](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py#L168) that code erroneously grabs the `"Undersampler.y"` output **and appends it to the input of the next component**, which in automl and in our reproducer happens to be the estimator. This is why one of the stack traces at the bottom comes from the estimator and mentions too many features being present.

**Solution**
This PR has a quick fix to change `BaseSampler.transform` to return None instead of y. This means that [when the features are computed for each transformer](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py#L168), the resulting component output dict will no longer contain a key `"Undersampler.y"`.

Long-term: we need to add test coverage to ensure all pipeline methods work properly for components which modify the target like the undersampler.

@dsherry had a spike which cleans up the component graph impl and would fix this issue, #2110 . And another spike #2210 which simplifies the sampler API, although that wouldn't have fixed the issue here directly.

**Repro**
The following
```python
import pandas as pd
import evalml
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification
X, y = make_classification()
X = pd.DataFrame(X)
y = pd.Series(y)
pipeline = evalml.pipelines.BinaryClassificationPipeline(component_graph=['Undersampler', 'Elastic Net Classifier'])
pipeline.fit(X, y)
pipeline.predict(X)
evalml.model_understanding.calculate_permutation_importance(pipeline, X, y, objective='Log Loss Binary')
```
runs fine until the call to `calculate_permutation_importance`, which produces this stack trace
```bash
<ipython-input-13-98cd846c0e1d> in <module>
----> 1 evalml.model_understanding.calculate_permutation_importance(pipeline, X, y, objective='Log Loss Binary')
~/development/evalml/evalml/model_understanding/graphs.py in calculate_permutation_importance(pipeline, X, y, objective, n_repeats, n_jobs, random_seed)
--> 385         perm_importance = _fast_permutation_importance(pipeline, X, y, objective, n_repeats=n_repeats, n_jobs=n_jobs,
~/development/evalml/evalml/model_understanding/graphs.py in _fast_permutation_importance(pipeline, X, y, objective, n_repeats, n_jobs, random_seed)
--> 350     baseline_score = scorer(pipeline, precomputed_features, y, objective)
~/development/evalml/evalml/model_understanding/graphs.py in scorer(pipeline, features, y, objective)
--> 342             preds = pipeline.estimator.predict_proba(features)
~/development/evalml/evalml/pipelines/components/component_base_meta.py in _check_for_fit(self, X, y)
---> 27                 return method(self, X)
~/development/evalml/evalml/pipelines/components/estimators/estimator.py in predict_proba(self, X)
---> 79             pred_proba = self._component_obj.predict_proba(X)
... (and then more frames in sklearn linear estimator)

ValueError: X has 21 features per sample; expecting 20
```
If you run the above but add a name to the pd Series for the target, you get a slightly different stack trace ending with
```bash
ValueError: Input contains NaN, infinity or a value too large for dtype('float64').
```
because the component graph somehow ends up returning all-nans for the target passed from the undersampler to the target.

title: ComponentGraph does not respect dag structure

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
This came up during #2046

Repro
```python
from evalml.pipelines import Transformer, ComponentGraph
from evalml.utils import infer_feature_types
from sklearn.datasets import make_regression
import pytest
import numpy as np


class LogTransform(Transformer):
    name = "Log Transform"

    def __init__(self, parameters=None, random_seed=0):
        super().__init__(parameters={}, component_obj=None, random_seed=random_seed)

    def fit(self, X, y):
        return self

    def transform(self, X, y=None):
        if y is None:
            return X, y
        y = infer_feature_types(y)
        return X, infer_feature_types(np.log(y.to_series()))

    def inverse_transform(self, X, y=None):
        y = infer_feature_types(y)
        return X, infer_feature_types(np.exp(y.to_series()))


cg = ComponentGraph({"Imputer": ['Imputer'],
                     "Log": [LogTransform],
                     "ET": ["Extra Trees Regressor", "Imputer.x", "Log.y"],
                     "Log 2": [LogTransform],
                     "RandomForest": ["Random Forest Regressor", "Imputer.x", "Log 2.y"],
                     "Log 3": [LogTransform],
                     "Catboost": ["CatBoost Classifier", "Imputer.x", "Log 3.y"],
                     "Logistic Regression": ["Logistic Regression Classifier", "Catboost", "RandomForest", "ET"]})

X, y = make_regression(n_samples=100, n_features=20, n_informative=3, random_state=0)
y = np.abs(y)
X = np.abs(X)

with pytest.raises(ValueError, match='Input contains NaN'):
    cg.instantiate({})
    cg.fit(X, y)
```

The problem is that the component graph uses the output of the "previous component" when the given component has no y parent ([code](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/component_graph.py#L234)).

In this particular case, that means that the random forest gets a target that's been logged twice (as opposed to once) and taking the log twice in this case creates nans (because after the first log, some values are negative).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/117892353-95971380-b286-11eb-8ba5-dc8d158ef635.png)

title: AutoMLSearch makes a reference to itself

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
AutoMLSearch makes a reference to itself via the `PipelineSearchPlot`. This will prevent the garbage collector from freeing up the memory taken up by AutoMLSearch. 

I was able to verify this by using this script from this [blog post](https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/python-cookbook/0596001673/ch14s10.html):

```python
import gc
import pandas as pd


def dump_garbage():
    gc.collect()

    print("\nUNCOLLECTABLE OBJECTS:")
    print(set(type(x) for x in gc.garbage))


def non_leaky_list():
    l = []
    l.append(1)
    del l
    dump_garbage()


def leaky_list():
    l = []
    l.append(l)
    del l
    dump_garbage()


def make_automl():
    from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
    from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
    from evalml.tuners import SKOptTuner

    X, y = load_breast_cancer()
    automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, "binary")
    del automl
    dump_garbage()


if __name__ == "__main__":
    gc.enable()
    gc.set_debug(gc.DEBUG_SAVEALL)
    print("Non Leaky List")
    non_leaky_list()
    print("Leaky list")
    leaky_list()
    print("Make AutoMLSearch")
    make_automl()
```

The output should be the following. You should be able to see `<class 'evalml.automl.automl_search.AutoMLSearch'>` and also all of the classes created during AutoMLSearch initialization, like `ComponentGraph`, `AutoMLConfig` and the data splitters. 

I don't think we'll be able to get rid of the skopt objects (`Categorical`, etc) because they are used to define component hyperparameters which are attacked to the component classes (which need to be imported by automl search).

from evalml.pipelines.components import Transformer

title: Don't use filepath in callback's logged message

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Our `raise_error_callback` and `log_error_callback` functions use the logger created by our `get_logger` util. 

This is problematic because pipeline evaluation could be happening in parallel so different workers could be attempting to write to the same file at the same time. Moreover, the computation could be happening in a remote machine, so the file that's written to would not be a file accessible by a user. I think the right thing to do is to use to `JobLogger` introduced in #1975 and add that as an argument to the callbacks. 

There's also another bug with our `log_error_callback`. It attempts to display the log filename but this may not exist depending on the value of the `EVALML_DEBUG_LOG` env variable. I think this is bad because it means search will end as soon as the first pipeline errors out. That's not what we want to happen.


Repro - first set `EVALML_DEBUG_LOG` to a non-writable path:

```python
import os
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
import pytest

X, y = load_breast_cancer()

class PipeLine(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    component_graph = ["Logistic Regression Classifier"]
    
    def fit(self, X, y):
        raise ValueError("Can't fit!")

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, problem_type="binary", allowed_pipelines=[PipeLine])

with pytest.raises(IndexError, match="list index out of range"):
    automl.search()
```

The line in question is ` logger.info(f"\t\t\tFold {fold_num}: Please check {logger.handlers[1].baseFilename} for the current hyperparameters and stack trace.")`

Maybe we should say `Please check the log file for the current hyperparameters and strack trace` ?

body:
Following up on #2139 , it seems our notebook lead_scoring notebook sometimes shows contradictory modeling performance.  

From #2139 :

> Found that when we leave the data splitter as it was, the AUC for the LeadScoring-optimized search was 0.5 since it always guessed the same output. This is likely because balancing the data in this scenario leads to no learning done. If the data is balanced 1:4, as long as the gain outweighs the loss, we will always predict the same output. I changed the sampling to be smaller in order to highlight the point we wanted to convey.
> This previous version is similar to our current performance
> We note that we've had many iterations where the performance was very poor:
[v13](https://evalml.alteryx.com/en/v0.13.1/demos/lead_scoring.html#Describe-pipeline)
[v17](https://evalml.alteryx.com/en/v0.17.0/demos/lead_scoring.html#Evaluate-on-hold-out)
[v19](https://evalml.alteryx.com/en/v0.19.0/demos/lead_scoring.html#Evaluate-on-hold-out)
[v20](https://evalml.alteryx.com/en/v0.20.0/demos/lead_scoring.html#Evaluate-on-hold-out)

Closing Criteria: determine why this is happening and implement the long term solution going forward.

title: AutoMLSearch does not apply pipeline_parameters to custom pipelines

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from skopt.space import Categorical
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
import pytest


class PipeLine(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    component_graph = ["One Hot Encoder", "Random Forest Classifier"]
    
X, y = load_breast_cancer()
automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, problem_type="binary", allowed_pipelines=[PipeLine],
                      pipeline_parameters={"Random Forest Classifier": {"n_estimators": Categorical([50])}},
                      max_batches=2)
automl.search()

rf_params = automl.full_rankings.iloc[:-1].parameters.map(lambda d: d["Random Forest Classifier"]['n_estimators'])

assert set(rf_params) != {50}
```

I think the issue is that `pipeline_parameters` [is only used](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_search.py#L291) in `allowed_pipelines` is None.

title: AutoMLSearch can't tune pipeline with custom hyperparameters if default param not in custom range

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from skopt.space import Categorical
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
import pytest


class PipelineDict(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    custom_hyperparameters = {"One Hot Encoder": {"top_n": Categorical([20])}}
    component_graph = {"One Hot Encoder": ["One Hot Encoder"],
                       "Random Forest Classifier": ["Random Forest Classifier", "One Hot Encoder"]}
    
X, y = load_breast_cancer()
automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, problem_type="binary", allowed_pipelines=[PipelineDict],
                      max_batches=2)
with pytest.raises(ValueError,
                   match="Default parameters for components in pipeline Pipeline Dict not in the hyperparameter ranges"):
    automl.search()
```

I think the problem is that the first batch uses the default parameters. When we call `add_result` with a set of hyperparameters that are not in the range that we use to create the tuner, skopt will throw an error.

We have a [mechanism to deal with this](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_algorithm/iterative_algorithm.py#L141) when the user specifies custom parameters with `pipeline_params` AutoMLSearch argument but we don't use it for custom_hyperparameter ranges.

I think this is a point in favor of deprecating the custom hyperparameters for pipelines like we discussed doing for #2091. In my opinion, the root cause is that we have two apis for overriding the hyperparameters used in search and we're struggling to maintain both of them.

title: AutoMLSearch: clean up API for freezing parameters and constraining hyperparam ranges

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

milestone.title: One Week Sprint
milestone.description: Catch up sprint to get N'Sync with other teams.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from skopt.space import Categorical
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
import pytest

X, y = load_breast_cancer()    

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, problem_type="binary",
                      max_batches=2,
                      pipeline_parameters={"Imputer": {"numeric_impute_strategy": "most_frequent"}})
automl.search()
all_imputer_params = automl.full_rankings.iloc[:-1].parameters.map(lambda d: d['Imputer']['numeric_impute_strategy'])
assert set(all_imputer_params) == {'most_frequent', 'mean'}
```

However using `skopt.space.Categorical` works.

```python
automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, problem_type="binary",
                      max_batches=2,
                      pipeline_parameters={"Imputer": {"numeric_impute_strategy": Categorical(["most_frequent"])}})
automl.search()
all_imputer_params = automl.full_rankings.iloc[:-1].parameters.map(lambda d: d['Imputer']['numeric_impute_strategy'])
assert set(all_imputer_params) == {'most_frequent'}
```

I think the problem is that skopt does not recognize `most_frequent` as a valid hyperparameter space so it will silently not include it in the `proposed_parameters` dict. Note that we can't specify `["most_frequent"]` because of #2028. 

I think the right thing to do is to not let users pass in "scalar-valued" hyperparameters.

title: Pipeline custom hyperparameters don't work for linear pipelines with duplicate components

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from skopt.space import Integer
class PipeLineLinear(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    custom_hyperparameters = {"One Hot Encoder_1": {"top_n": Integer(10, 50)}}
    component_graph = ["One Hot Encoder", "One Hot Encoder", "Random Forest Classifier"]

assert "One Hot Encoder_1" not in PipeLineLinear.hyperparameters
assert PipeLineLinear.hyperparameters == {'One Hot Encoder': {},
                                         'Random Forest Classifier': {'n_estimators': Integer(10, 1000),
                                                                      'max_depth': Integer(1, 10)}}
```

There is no problem when the component graph is specified as a dictionary:

```python
class PipeLineDict(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    custom_hyperparameters = {"OHE_1": {"top_n": Integer(10, 50)}}
    component_graph = {"OHE": ["One Hot Encoder"],
                       "OHE_1": ["One Hot Encoder", "OHE"],
                       "Random Forest Classifier": ["Random Forest Classifier", "OHE_1"]}

assert PipeLineDict.hyperparameters == {"OHE": {},
                                        "OHE_1": {"top_n": Integer(10, 50)},
                                        'Random Forest Classifier': {'n_estimators': Integer(10, 1000),
                                                                      'max_depth': Integer(1, 10)}}
```


This is similar to #2049

title: Partial dependence not respecting grid_resolution parameter for numeric features

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Issues tracking performance improvements.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.demos import load_fraud
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from evalml.model_understanding import partial_dependence
import pytest

X, y = load_fraud(1000)

class Pipeline(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    component_graph = ["DateTime Featurization Component", "One Hot Encoder", "Random Forest Classifier"]

pl = Pipeline({})
pl.fit(X, y)

dep = partial_dependence(pl, X, features="amount", grid_resolution=20)

# Doesn't use the grid_resolution I passed in
assert dep.shape[0] != 20

# Instead uses 1 + the max cardinality of categorical features
assert dep.shape[0] ==  max(X.select('categorical').describe().loc["nunique"]) + 1
```

In order to support categorical features, we need to set the `grid_resolution` to 1 + the cardinality of the desired categorical feature. However, we should only do that when the feature the user passes in is categorical.

title: Baseline pipeline reported as having high classification accuracy

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
On this imbalanced binary classification dataset, when "accuracy binary" is selected as the objective, the baseline model is reported to have performed the _best_ of all pipelines. This is incorrect by definition!

**Repro**
(Make sure you use woodwork 0.0.11 since we don't yet support 0.1.X)
Download [kaggle stroke prediction dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/fedesoriano/stroke-prediction-dataset)
Set "stroke" as the target
```
import evalml
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
df = pd.read_csv('/Users/dylan.sherry/Downloads/Stroke Predictors.csv')
dt = ww.DataTable(df)
y = dt.pop('stroke')
automl_acc = evalml.AutoMLSearch(X_train=dt, y_train=y, problem_type='binary', objective='accuracy binary')
automl_acc.search()
```
Note that the baseline model has the highest accuracy reported, tied with ElasticNet, at 0.951291. This is not correct!

If you run the same but with log loss or F1, the baseline model scores the worst as expected.

Per a conversation with Tom McGrath about what the error code meant led us into looking at the message.  It says this 👍

title: AutoML cannot handle updating pipelines parameters with duplicate components

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: needs design
labels.description: Issues requiring design documentation.

labels.name: spike
labels.description: To generate additional issues and kick off a sprint.

body:
If we have two OHEs, for example, we cannot set the parameters for the second OHE.

```
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch

X, y = load_breast_cancer() 
class PipeLine(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    component_graph = ["One Hot Encoder", "One Hot Encoder", "Random Forest Classifier"]

automl = AutoMLSearch(X, y, problem_type="binary", allowed_pipelines=[PipeLine], pipeline_parameters={"One Hot Encoder": {"top_n":100},
                                                                                                      "One Hot Encoder_1": {"top_n":1}}) 
automl.search()
```

This search runs fine, but looking at a pipeline:
```
automl.get_pipeline(1)
```

Gives...
```
PipeLine(parameters={'One Hot Encoder':{'top_n': 100, 'features_to_encode': None, 'categories': None, 'drop': 'if_binary', 'handle_unknown': 'ignore', 'handle_missing': 'error'}, 'One Hot Encoder_1':{'top_n': 10, 'features_to_encode': None, 'categories': None, 'drop': 'if_binary', 'handle_unknown': 'ignore', 'handle_missing': 'error'}, 'Random Forest Classifier':{'n_estimators': 100, 'max_depth': 6, 'n_jobs': -1},})
```

Notice that the second OHE (One Hot Encoder_1) holds the default parameters, and not the specified ones.

title: Calculating for high variance when the mean of cv_scores is zero

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: spike
labels.description: To generate additional issues and kick off a sprint.

body:
Right now, our calculation for high variance is:
```
        cv_scores_std = cv_scores.std()
        cv_scores_mean = cv_scores.mean()
        if cv_scores_std != 0 and cv_scores_mean != 0:
            high_variance_cv = bool(abs(cv_scores_std / cv_scores_mean) > threshold)```
```

This was put in place to prevent a divide-by-zero warning / error. However, this impl is not ideal: if the mean is close to zero (but not zero), high variance will likely be true (dividing by small number). 

In addition, it is possible for there to be high variance if the mean is zero but the standard deviation is very high. Right now, we default to False but we may want to look for a impl that is smarter in this situation.

title: Allow components which are not "leaf" children in the class hierarchy

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
In working on #1989, @freddyaboulton suggested that we make `TargetImputer` a subclass of `SimpleImputer`. Unfortunately, when looking for viable components in `_get_subclasses`, `_get_subclasses` will only collect classes that are at the very bottom of the hierarchy. For example:
```
ComponentBase --> Transformer --> SimpleImputer # will only grab SimpleImputer

```

The issue is, if we subclass SimpleImputer, we will have access to TargetImputer, but `SimpleImputer` will no longer be found by EvalML as a useable component:

```
ComponentBase --> Transformer --> SimpleImputer --> TargetImputer 
# will only grab TargetImputer, SimpleImputer is no longer a leaf

```

I believe the original intent is to not grab classes that are not useful (ex: Transformer), but this is a problem if we want to build upon useful components to create new ones.

Original comment here: https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/1989#discussion_r599894996

title: AutoMLSearch.train_pipelines does not apply undersampling

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
If users run `AutoMLSearch` with an imbalanced dataset, `AutoMLSearch` will use undersampling by default. 

Our current behavior is to train all pipelines with the undersampling. This is taken care of by the sampler's `split` method during search and in the `_find_best_pipeline` method when `AutoMLSearch` goes to train the best pipeline.

The undersampling is [missing](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/engine/sequential_engine.py#L59) from the `train_batch` logic of the engine and should be added.

title: Fix TS Pipelines to encode target data for both predict and predict_proba

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Minimum repro:
```python
from evalml.pipelines import TimeSeriesBinaryClassificationPipeline
import pandas as pd

class TSBinaryPipeline(TimeSeriesBinaryClassificationPipeline):
        """Logistic Regression Pipeline for time series binary classification problems."""
        component_graph = ['Delayed Feature Transformer', 'Logistic Regression Classifier']

X = pd.DataFrame({"A": [i for i in range(1000)]})
y = pd.Series(["String target {}".format(i % 2) for i in range(1000)])
ts_binary_pipeline = TSBinaryPipeline(parameters={"Logistic Regression Classifier": {"n_jobs": 1}, "pipeline": {"gap": 0, "max_delay": 0}})
ts_binary_pipeline.fit(X, y)
pred_proba = ts_binary_pipeline.predict_proba(X, y)
```
Results in:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22552445/110978887-eabfb300-8331-11eb-818f-b4e8bc633f0c.png)

This issue tracks fixing this (likely adding the call to the target encoder in `predict` and `predict_proba`), then adding in an equivalent test as `test_binary_pipeline_string_target_thresholding` in `test_pipelines` to the `time_series_pipeline` tests.

title: v0.18.2 Perf Test Results

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: spike
labels.description: To generate additional issues and kick off a sprint.

body:
In attempting to perform the 0.19.0 release, I got some weird results with respect to the 0.18.2 perf tests.  See https://alteryx.quip.com/DsyEAqnI1tRh/v0190-vs-v0182-perf-test-results#dERACA7df0O, "Anomalies" section for a description.  This should be analyzed a little more to ensure that something strange hasn't crept into the baseline.

In short, the response json from looking glass contained something like this.

`{"results": [{"dataset": "abalone.csv", "trials": [{"measurements": [{"measurement_name": "error_type", "measurement_value": "<class 'TypeError'>"}, {"measurement_name": "error_message", "measurement_value": "split_data() got an unexpected keyword argument 'random_seed'"}, {"measurement_name": "error_traceback", "measurement_value": "  File \"looking_glass/container/perf_test_runner.py\", line 228, in run\n    trial_measurements_dict = measure_evalml_automl(X, y,\n  File \"/evalml_looking_glass/looking_glass/container/evalml_runner.py\", line 50, in measure_evalml_automl\n    X_train, X_validation, y_train, y_validation = split_data(X, y, problem_type=problem_type,\n"}], "metadata": [{"metadata_name": "random_seed", "metadata_value": "0"}, {"metadata_name": "max_iterations", "metadata_value": "14"}, {"metadata_name": "max_batches", "metadata_value": "None"}, {"metadata_name": "evalml_automl_arguments", "metadata_value": "{}"}, {"metadata_name": "evalml_search_arguments", "metadata_value": "{}"}, {"metadata_name": "evalml_branch", "metadata_value": "v0.18.2"}, {"metadata_name": "evalml_hash", "metadata_value": 
`

The presence of the "random_seed" reference raises some questions.  Was the release branch modified after the perf tests were run?  Did the deprecation explain_prediction() #1822 story get merged in after the release branch was cut?

These issues seem to go away with the latests release, but we might want to investigate this a little further.

title: Handle deprecation warnings properly in the documentation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Issues which would be a good starting point for new hires.

body:
Per the previous release and the deprecation warnings applied to explain_prediction() in #1822 , deprecation errors crop up in the user facing docs.  https://feature-labs-inc-evalml--1874.com.readthedocs.build/en/1874/demos/fraud.html. These will naturally disappear with the completion of #1832 , but it will be best to tackle this now as part of our preparation to adopt the process of deprecating functions in this way.

No bueno.  So we need to come up with a solution that handles this for all the user-facing docs.  It's good that a user sees a warning when working in their console or IDE, but we don't want this in the docs.  Curiously, when I try to reproduce locally, I do not get the warnings on my local jupyter notebook.  We should explore whether there's some global warning suppression that we can perform on the documentation.

More than likely, this issue won't be completed before the explain_prediction() is removed.  If a good test needs to be made, checkout v. 0.19.0 and see how the explain_prediction() function was deprecated and replicate that as a starting point.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64713315/108951412-ee66f080-7635-11eb-8379-37e0fa6d1d72.png)

title: Automl does not use objective decision function during scoring

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Our classification pipeline uses the `_compute_predictions` method in `score` to get the predicted labels and probabilities. 

However, `_compute_predictions` [does not pass the objective](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/classification_pipeline.py#L138) to the pipeline `predict` method.  

Is this intended?

title: Pipeline Parameters: Warn/Raise on Extra Parameters

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Issues which would be a good starting point for new hires.

body:
When parameters are passed in as a dictionary to instantiate a pipeline, the pipeline takes what it needs and passes the parameters up to the __init__ of it's parent class.  The parent class then takes that dictionary of parameters and iterates through the components the user has placed in the pipeline, pulling the parameters for the component that match the key in the parameters dictionary.  

I've run into one case that I don't think exhibits proper behavior: if the supplied parameters contain excess parameters for components that are not in the pipeline.

Repro:
```
from evalml.pipelines import TimeSeriesRegressionPipeline

class TSPipeline(TimeSeriesRegressionPipeline):
    component_graph = ["Delayed Feature Transformer", "Random Forest Regressor"]
    name = "time series pipeline"

tspipeline = TSPipeline({"pipeline": {"gap": 1, "max_delay": 2},
                             "Linear Regressor": {"n_jobs": 1}})
```

Options for desired behavior:

1. Continue to do nothing.  Sub-optimal as a user has tried to set parameters on something and the default parameters will be used instead.  This could lead to very tough to catch misbehavior for unaware users (like me).
2. Communicate a warning indicating that the supplied parameters will be ignored and the pointing out which components will be instantiated with defaults.
3. (Preferred) Raise a ValueError indicating that parameters were provided for non-existent components.

A good place to start looking is in evalml/pipeplines/component_graph.py::ComponentGraph.instantiate().  A simple comparison of keys to the component graph's components will probably lead to 2 or 3 being complete.

title: Binary Classification Pipeline  predict method does not use objective if it is passed as a named argument

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro:

```python
from evalml.objectives import BinaryClassificationObjective
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.pipelines import BinaryClassificationPipeline
import pandas as pd
from unittest.mock import MagicMock


class Pipeline(BinaryClassificationPipeline):
    component_graph = ["Random Forest Classifier"]


X, y = load_breast_cancer()


class CustomObjective(BinaryClassificationObjective):
    greater_is_better = False
    name = "Foo Objective"
    perfect_score = 0
    score_needs_proba = False
    
    def objective_function(self, y_true, y_predicted, X=None):
        pass
    
    def decision_function(self, ypred_proba, threshold, X):
        # The decoder will map 0 to benign so we should expect the
        # predictions to only contain "benign"
        return pd.Series([0] * len(ypred_proba))


pipeline = Pipeline({})
pipeline.fit(X, y)
pipeline._threshold = 0.3
expected_preds = ['benign'] * len(y)

assert not pipeline.predict(X, objective=CustomObjective()).to_series().tolist() == expected_preds
```

The strange thing is that it works as expected if the objective is not used as a kwarg:

```python
assert pipeline.predict(X, CustomObjective()).to_series().tolist() == expected_preds
```

The problem is in the pipeline meta class. If the objective is passed as a kwarg, then `y=None` and we [don't pass the objective to the method](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/pipeline_base_meta.py#L25).

title: Unit tests in build_conda_pkg job timing out after woodwork component PR merge

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to testing.

labels.name: blocker
labels.description: An issue blocking a release.

body:
**Background**
@angela97lin merged #1668 yesterday, which updated our components to return woodwork datatables and pass those along to the next component in the graph during pipeline graph evaluation. We think this slowed down our pipeline graph evaluation a bit. The benefit from that was that any user-overridden woodwork types are now accessible by each component during fit/evaluate.

We've also been tracking a performance issue in permutation importance: #1416. Essentially, our current permutation importance algorithm is doing more pipeline evaluations than it needs to.

The build_conda_pkg job runs on each merge to `main`. It aims to check that we haven't broken the ability to build our conda package, so we have the ability to make a conda release. Currently, it runs all the unit tests inside a docker container, single-threaded (no particular reason its single-threaded).

**Symptoms**
After @angela97lin merged the woodwork pipeline update, the build_conda_pkg job [has been consistently timing out](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml/9311/workflows/52b060b5-f929-4945-8ccd-cbd8b50496bd/jobs/110048) while running the unit tests:
```python
evalml/tests/data_checks_tests/test_target_leakage_data_check.py ....... [ 58%]
......                                                                   [ 58%]
evalml/tests/demo_tests/test_datasets.py .....                           [ 59%]
evalml/tests/model_family_tests/test_model_family.py .....               [ 59%]
evalml/tests/model_understanding_tests/test_graphs.py .................. [ 59%]

Too long with no output (exceeded 10m0s): context deadline exceeded
```

**Hypothesis**
* The woodwork pipeline PR introduced a slight slowdown in pipeline evaluation
* We know the permutation importance algorithm is doing more pipeline evaluations than it needs to be doing, amplifying any time increase from pipeline evaluation
* The `test_graph.py` unit tests run permutation importance once with every objective we support, AKA a lot
* The build_conda_pkg job runs the unit tests with a single thread, whereas our test_linux_all job runs with 8 workers.

**Next Steps**
* Do what we can to have the unit tests run in as similar a manner as possible between test_linux_all and build_conda_pkg, and see what happens
    * Experiment: try creating a spike copy of the build_conda_pkg job which runs with 8 workers.
    * If this resolves the issue, that's compelling evidence that our hypothesis is correct. If not, 🤷‍♂️
* Speed up the tests. Update `test_graphs.py` to use mocking instead of running permutation importance in full once per objective
* Speed up permutation importance (#1416, @freddyaboulton )

@angela97lin @freddyaboulton

title: Custom woodwork types aren't preserved in components

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
EDIT: following #1668, updating this issue.

**Problem**
Our components currently do not preserve the input custom woodwork types. After #1668, we updated automl and `ComponentGraph` to keep track of custom Woodwork types, such that if a user overrides a Woodwork type, it will be passed from component to component successfully. However, this is not true on a Component level: if a user passes an overridden Woodwork column to only a component, they will find that the returned Woodwork data structure did not preserve the override. That's odd.

**Symptoms**
User using Component will notice that evalml will reset any overridden Woodwork types.

**Fix**
Update all transformers `transform` to return Woodwork with the original overridden types, if applicable.

Note:
This behavior is relevant only in components where the original column should be preserved. In some cases, such as the standard scaler, type change is expected. In other cases, such as the OHE, the original column is removed and this doesn't apply.

body:
Repro

```python
from evalml.demos import load_diabetes
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch

X, y = load_diabetes()
y = y.to_series()
y = -1 * y

search = AutoMLSearch(X_train=X, y_train=y, problem_type='regression')
search.search()
```

  File "/Users/freddy.boulton/miniconda3/envs/evalml/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sklearn/metrics/_regression.py", line 334, in mean_squared_log_error

I think the issue is that the `only_postive` objectives were recently removed from the non-core objectives. I think we should mark them again as non-core. They can still be used if they are provided as instances.

title: Get rid of the `random_state` argument in `get_pipeline`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Currently, the `best_pipeline` property in `AutoMLSearch` will [always return](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_search.py#L530) a pipeline with `random_state=0` because that's the default value for `random_state` in the `get_pipeline` method.

I think this is confusing because if I create an `AutoMLSearch` object with `random_state=5`, for example, I expect all of the pipelines created and returned by `AutoMLSearch` to have `random_state=5`.

I think we should remove the `random_state` argument from `get_pipeline` and instead make sure that the random state is set to whatever it was when the pipeline was fit.

title: Pass gap and max_delay to baseline estimator in AutoMLSearch for time series problems

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
This is currently how we create the baseline pipeline for time series problems:

```python
gap = self.problem_configuration['gap']
max_delay = self.problem_configuration['max_delay']
baseline = TimeSeriesBaselineRegressionPipeline(parameters={"pipeline": {"gap": gap, "max_delay": max_delay}})
```

We need to pass gap and max delay to the estimator:

```python
gap = self.problem_configuration['gap']
max_delay = self.problem_configuration['max_delay']
baseline = TimeSeriesBaselineRegressionPipeline(parameters={"pipeline": {"gap": gap, "max_delay": max_delay},
"Time Series Baseline Regressor": {"gap": gap, "max_delay": max_delay}})
```

body:
Repro:
```python
from evalml.objectives import MAPE, MSE
import pandas as pd

y_pred = pd.Series([1, 2, 3], index=['a', 'b', 'c'])
y_true = pd.Series([2, 3, 4])

assert pd.isna(MAPE().objective_function(y_pred, y_true))
```

Our other objectives support custom indices:

assert MSE().objective_function(y_pred, y_true) == 1.0
```

title: Stacked ensembler: use same CV data splitter as the rest of automl

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Currently, the stacked ensembler has its own setup for CV. `IterativeAlgorithm` calls [the `_make_stacked_ensembler` util](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/utils.py#L221), but doesn't currently thread through the data splitter from automl search.

[The data splitter set up by default in the stacked ensembler](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/components/ensemble/stacked_ensemble_base.py#L53) doesn't set `shuffle=True`, which [could lead to poor performance](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/1259) if the input dataset has an ordering. It also won't have the same settings for other parameters like `n_folds`, which isn't ideal.

Also, this difference [is preventing us from supporting sklearn 0.24.0](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/1591). Fixing this issue should allow us to support that version.

**Fix**
Let's have automl pass its data splitter through `IterativeAlgorithm` down into the stacked ensembler.

title: Impute NaNs for natural language features

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: An improvement to an existing feature.

body:
In #1492, we realized the `LSA` transformer errors when there are NaNs in one of the feature columns. Should the `LSA` transformer handle NaNs "gracefully" like the `nlp_primitives` used in the `TextFeaturizer` or should we update the `Imputer` to impute text columns?

This is the reproducer/original comment on #1492 that lead us to open this issue:

I think the root cause is that there are NaNs in the `job` column and this causes the `TfidfVectorizer` in LSA to crash. You can reproduce this locally:

```python
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer
import pandas as pd
import woodwork as ww
from urllib.request import urlopen
customers_data = urlopen('https://featurelabs-static.s3.amazonaws.com/lead_scoring_ml_apps/customers.csv')
interactions_data = urlopen('https://featurelabs-static.s3.amazonaws.com/lead_scoring_ml_apps/interactions.csv')
leads_data = urlopen('https://featurelabs-static.s3.amazonaws.com/lead_scoring_ml_apps/previous_leads.csv')
customers = pd.read_csv(customers_data)
interactions = pd.read_csv(interactions_data)
leads = pd.read_csv(leads_data)

X = customers.merge(interactions, on='customer_id').merge(leads, on='customer_id')
y = X['label']
X = X.drop(['customer_id', 'date_registered', 'birthday','phone', 'email',
            'owner', 'company', 'id', 'time_x',
            'session', 'referrer', 'time_y', 'label', 'country'], axis=1)
TfidfVectorizer().fit_transform(X['job'])
```

Dropping NaNs fixes the issue:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/102243772-85daf500-3ec9-11eb-81ec-47d473c9630b.png)


All of our AutoML pipelines have an Imputer. So I think the true bug is that the imputer does not impute NaNs for the `job` column!

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/102244251-0c8fd200-3eca-11eb-8499-c20d3fba7429.png)

This is because the Imputer will only impute [categorical columns, not text](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/components/transformers/imputers/imputer.py#L67). When we convert to pandas from ww, text columns get converted to `object`. 

The question now is "where should NaNs be handled for text columns"?. I think we have two options:
1. Update the Imputer to handle text columns.
2. Interestingly, the `LSA` transformer comes after the `nlp_primitives` are finished computing features. That makes me think that the `nlp_primitives` DFS naturally handle NaNs  whereas `LSA` does not. Should that feature be added to LSA @eccabay ? 
3. Both

What do you guys think?

_Originally posted by @freddyaboulton in https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/issues/1492#issuecomment-745414068_

title: Fix Automl custom objective stack trace

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
### Pull Request Description
Fixes #1572 

The issue is that `_compute_cv_scores` stores the objective scores in a dict keyed by the objective name (str). When we go to compute "percent better than baseline", we have to map the string name to an objective class. We were doing this mapping with `get_objective` which doesn't doesn't know about the class definition of a custom objective. 

The fix is to create a name to class mapping when AutoMLSearch is created.

-----
*After creating the pull request: in order to pass the **release_notes_updated** check you will need to update the "Future Release" section of* `docs/source/release_notes.rst` *to include this pull request by adding :pr:`123`.*

title: AutoML errors if objective is defined as valid for both binary and multiclass

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Our [code in automl search](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_search.py#L662) which optimizes binary classification thresholding should only run if the problem type is "binary", not for "multiclass."

**Scope**
Nobody has encountered this because a) I see from `git blame` that we updated the offending `if` statements in early Nov, and b) most (all?) of [our current objectives](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/objectives/standard_metrics.py) are defined for only one problem type, not both binary and multiclass. So its a minor bug.

**Repro**
I wasn't able to test this because bug #1572 gets in the way, but I'm pretty sure the following will cause a stack trace independent of #1572: 
```python
import evalml
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn import metrics
class ClassificationObjective(evalml.objectives.ObjectiveBase):
    problem_types = [evalml.problem_types.ProblemTypes.BINARY, evalml.problem_types.ProblemTypes.MULTICLASS]
class ClassificationAccuracy(ClassificationObjective):
    """Accuracy score for binary and multiclass classification."""
    name = "Classification Accuracy"
    greater_is_better = True
    score_needs_proba = False
    perfect_score = 1.0

    def objective_function(self, y_true, y_predicted, X=None):
        return metrics.accuracy_score(y_true, y_predicted)
X, y = evalml.demos.load_wine()
automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(problem_type="multiclass", objective=ClassificationAccuracy())
automl.search(X, y)
```

**Fix**
Currently [that code](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_search.py#L662) checks `self.objective.is_defined_for_problem_type(ProblemTypes.BINARY)` in a couple places. I think it should do that but first also check `self.problem_type == ProblemTypes.BINARY`. Easy fix.

The code I linked to is in `_compute_cv_scores`; note @bchen1116 is adding similar code to `search` for fitting the best pipeline, in #1547

title: AutoML: pass number of CV folds to default data checks

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
RE @bchen1116 point [here](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/1568#pullrequestreview-554679046):

> [We should] update our implementation for class_imbalance_data_check, specifically the cv_folds arg [here](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/a48ebfb64a16688ee95047e53f4aced54755d23b/evalml/data_checks/class_imbalance_data_check.py#L17). It defaults to 3 since that's the default data split n_folds, but with this change, I believe we should update AutoMLSearch to pass in the required param.

I completely agree! Good eye 👀 

Filing as a bug because if someone customizes the data splitter passed to automl. the class imbalance data check won't get the right `n_folds` value and therefore isn't functioning exactly as designed.

title: AutoMLSearch uses slightly different splits for each pipeline

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro (need to checkout the `random-split-seeds` branch because we don't store the state of the random seed of the data split):

```python
from evalml.demos import load_breast_cancer
from evalml.automl import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.utils.gen_utils import check_random_state_equality
import numpy as np
import itertools

def make_seed_from_state(state):
    rs = np.random.RandomState()
    rs.set_state(state)
    return rs

def check_random_state(state_1, state_2):
    rs_1 = make_seed_from_state(state_1)
    rs_2 = make_seed_from_state(state_2)
    return check_random_state_equality(rs_1, rs_2)

X, y = load_breast_cancer()

automl = AutoMLSearch(max_batches=2, problem_type="binary")
automl.search(X, y)

seeds_equal = []
for i, j in itertools.combinations(range(14), 2): 
    are_equal = check_random_state(automl.data_split_seeds[i], automl.data_split_seeds[j])
    seeds_equal.append(are_equal)
    
assert not all(seeds_equal)
```

The issue with having a different random state everytime `data_split.split` is called is that the split will be slightly different each time:
```python
from sklearn.model_selection import StratifiedKFold
seed_1 = make_seed_from_state(automl.data_split_seeds[0])
seed_2 = make_seed_from_state(automl.data_split_seeds[1])
split_1 = StratifiedKFold(n_splits=3, random_state=seed_1, shuffle=True)
split_2 = StratifiedKFold(n_splits=3, random_state=seed_2, shuffle=True)

for (train_index_1, test_index_1), (train_index_2, test_index_2) in zip(split_1.split(X, y), split_2.split(X, y)):
    assert not set(train_index_1) == set(train_index_2)
    assert not set(test_index_1) == set(test_index_2)
```

I think we should change this because it is introducing more variability into the results of automl than is necessary and prevents a true apples-to-apples comparison between pipelines. That being said, I don't think fixing this would substantially impact the results of automl search (the pipeline ranking would probably be the same). 


One possible solution is to create the split class with an integer random seed as opposed to the `np.random.RandomState` that is stored in the automl state. I believe the indices will be the same in repeated calls:

```python
from sklearn.model_selection import StratifiedKFold
split_1 = StratifiedKFold(n_splits=3, random_state=10, shuffle=True)

first_train_set = []
first_test_set = []
for (train_index_1, test_index_1) in split_1.split(X, y):
    first_train_set.append(set(train_index_1))
    first_test_set.append(set(test_index_1))

second_train_set = []
second_test_set = []
for (train_index_2, test_index_2) in split_1.split(X, y):
    second_train_set.append(set(train_index_2))
    second_test_set.append(set(test_index_2))

assert first_train_set == second_train_set
assert first_test_set == second_test_set
```

title: For some datasets, percent_better_than_baseline_all_objectives is huge because baseline values are infinitesimal

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
I tested the `percent_better_than_baseline_all_objectives` values on a few datasets and found that `ExpVariance` on two of them was enormous. On `retail_data.csv` it's `1.4857769515459812e+18`.

Turns out this is because the cv objective scores for the baseline was infinitesimal:

```python
for scores in automl.results['pipeline_results'][0]['cv_data']:
    print(scores['all_objective_scores']['ExpVariance'])
```

```
0.0
0.0
1.1102230246251565e-16
```

With `evalml 0.13.2` these were all zero.

Now, obviously there's variability in this kind of thing, but it seems like `1.1102230246251565e-16` is a rounding error, not a real, valid value for this metric.

Here's the reproducer:

```python
import evalml
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
import pandas as pd

data = pd.read_csv('datasets/retail/retail_data.csv')
data = data.drop(['cancelled'], axis=1)

y = data['total']
X = data.drop(['total'], axis=1)

automl = AutoMLSearch(problem_type="regression", objective="Root Mean Squared Error", max_iterations=3)
automl.search(X, y)

# oh, I miss Scala
if automl.data_check_results is not None:
    for boom in automl.data_check_results:
        print(boom)

print(f'pipline 2 ExpVariance: {automl.results["pipeline_results"][2]["percent_better_than_baseline_all_objectives"]["ExpVariance"]}')


for scores in automl.results['pipeline_results'][0]['cv_data']:
    print(f'cv ExpVariance: {scores["all_objective_scores"]["ExpVariance"]}')

```

title: Imputer changes index on X

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
The Imputer calls `.reset_index()` in the `transform` method. I don't think we should do this because some downstream components/processing might (reasonably) assume that X and y have the same index, e.g. pandas groupby.

Repro:

```python
from evalml.demos import load_diabetes
from evalml.pipelines.components import Imputer
import pandas as pd

X, y = load_diabetes()

X.index = range(1000, 1000 + X.shape[0])

X_imputed = Imputer().fit_transform(X)

pd.testing.assert_index_equal(X.index, X_imputed.index)
```

title: Unit tests use up to 20GB of memory on circleci

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to testing.

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Issues tracking performance improvements.

body:
**Problem**
While debugging intermittent test failures on PR #1410, @christopherbunn and I measured memory usage of the unit tests on circleci and found a complete end-to-end run can use up to 20GB at peak.

That's way more than I would have expected... the question is, why?

**Observations**
We ssh'ed into a circleci box running on `main` and ran the following [using `memory-profiler`](https://pypi.org/project/memory-profiler/):
```python
mprof run  --include-children pytest evalml/ -n 8 --doctest-modules --cov=evalml --junitxml=test-reports/junit.xml --doctest-continue-on-failure -v
```
Which created the following plot, visible with `mprof plot`:
![mprof_4.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5dd2ce3698e0b800015f2d7a/a8e80273-e9ad-4996-aaee-ff18d8d19075)

I ran this twice and got a similar plot, so the results appear to be consistent across runs.

This is dangerously close to the max memory allowed on the circleci worker size we're using. That's why we started looking into this -- on #1410, we saw that the memory usage went 5GB higher for some reason.

title: Unit test flake: pipeline tests failing intermittently with timeout/error

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Background**
@christopherbunn and I started noticing this on his PR #1337. For the past ~10 days or so, some of the pipeline unit tests would fail on linux, intermittently. However, that PR didn't make any changes to the pipeline code, just automl, so we concluded his PR couldn't have introduced the problem and merged today.

Here's all the CI runs [on the branch for #1337](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml?branch=1295_%60_evaluate%60_changes). Here's a few failures:
* [Link](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml/7032/workflows/62643932-c75c-42cb-bc72-a82a3a893525/jobs/77814). `evalml.tests.pipeline_tests.test_pipelines::test_serialization` failed, stack trace goes into sklearn logistic regression code. Also `evalml.tests.pipeline_tests.test_pipelines::test_stacked_estimator_in_pipeline[binary]` failed with a stack trace going into random forest.
* [Link](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml/7047/workflows/23b2f335-9e59-4486-9690-6745464e8bb8/jobs/78077). This one timed out, probably a race condition / deadlock. It appears `evalml/tests/objective_tests/test_cost_benefit_matrix.py::test_cbm_objective_automl[True]` failed prior to this.
* [Link](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml/7047/workflows/ec6cb138-5217-436c-a7f6-f7566072b49a/jobs/78076). Another logistic failure. Unit test just creates a logreg pipeline and calls `fit`...
* [Link](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml/7047/workflows/886bf88b-e158-46b0-86da-9504104cad24/jobs/78035). This one failed in `test_stacked_estimator_in_pipeline[multiclass]` and `test_stacked_estimator_in_pipeline[regression]`

**Hypothesis**
I wonder if these tests are failing due to a bug in the stacked ensemble code, or other code which has been added recently which changes `n_jobs` or deals with concurrency.

**Next steps**
* Try running one of the failing tests 100x locally, see if we can repro
* Watch for more failures on `main` in the next couple weeks

title: Automl fails with custom pipelines if data contains datetime feature(s)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
#### Background
We're in a funny intermediate stage with adding support for woodwork in #1229. We've added support to automl `search`, but pipelines, components, `make_pipeline` and other utils still expect pandas `DataFrame`s.

Another fact which is important here: creating a woodwork `DataTable` will modify the types of the underlying pandas `DataFrame`

#### Problem
The following code doesn't work, borrowed from @bchen1116 's docs additions in his PR #1284 with some modifications for simplicity:
```python
import evalml
X, y = evalml.demos.load_fraud(n_rows=1000)

estimators = evalml.pipelines.components.utils.get_estimators('binary', [evalml.model_family.ModelFamily.EXTRA_TREES])
pipelines = [evalml.pipelines.utils.make_pipeline(X, y, estimator, 'binary') for estimator in estimators]
automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(problem_type='binary', allowed_pipelines=pipelines)
automl.search(X, y)
```
errors out with
```
AutoMLSearchException: All pipelines in the current AutoML batch produced a score of np.nan on the primary objective <evalml.objectives.standard_metrics.LogLossBinary object at 0x13ea47700>.
```

Reason: `make_pipeline` doesn't have access to the pandas DF. Because the datetime feature comes in with type "object" (string), `make_pipeline` won't know there's a datetime feature, and won't add the `DateTimeFeaturizer`.

Then, in automl search, because we use woodwork `DataTable`s in there right now, the datetime feature will get converted to type `datetime64`. When the pipeline is evaluated on that data, it'll break, because the `StandardScaler` will try to apply scaling to a `datetime64`-type column and will error out.

#### Workaround
The following code does work:
```python
import evalml
X, y = evalml.demos.load_fraud(n_rows=1000)
import woodwork as ww
X_dt = ww.DataTable(X)
y_dc = ww.DataColumn(y)

estimators = evalml.pipelines.components.utils.get_estimators('binary', [ModelFamily.EXTRA_TREES])
pipelines = [evalml.pipelines.utils.make_pipeline(X, y, estimator, 'binary') for estimator in estimators]
automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(problem_type='binary', allowed_pipelines=pipelines)
automl.search(X, y)
```

That's because calling `X_dt = ww.DataTable(X)` will modify the underlying pandas `DataFrame` to have type `datetime64` for the `datetime` feature. `make_pipeline` will correctly add a `DateTimeFeaturizer` to the pipeline, which will make datetime features and delete the original `datetime` feature. So, by the time the `StandardScaler` is run, there won't be a datetime feature passed in

#### Fix
Short-term: either use the workaround, or update `StandardScaler` to only be applied to numeric features, i.e. those with type `int`/`float` in the pandas DF.

Long-term: update `StandardScaler`, and `make_pipeline`, to use woodwork! `StandardScaler` should apply to any numeric feature, and `make_pipeline` should check if there's any datetime-typed features and use that to determine whether to add a `DateTimeFeaturizer`

This is why we're moving towards using woodwork: so the woodwork `DataTable` is a single source of truth on the type of each feature.

#### Next steps
My recommendation for this issue: make the update to `StandardScaler` now, because we'll have to make a similar update for #1229 anyways, so it won't be wasted work.

title: Don't add OneHotEncoder to pipeline for text features

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Our `make_pipelines` code builds a pipeline based on the feature types present in the data. The [`_get_preprocessing_components` method](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/utils.py#L66) will currently add a one-hot encoder component if there are any features of type `object` or `category` in the pandas dataframe. However, in the case where the data includes text features but no categorical features, this is unnecessary.

**Fix**
Short-term (this PR): during pipeline creation, exclude text features when determining whether or not to add an encoder for categorical features.

Long-term: use woodwork to get categorical cols, not pandas! (#1229 ). The `make_pipelines` code should be given a woodwork datatable, and we should instead use woodwork's select method.

title: Allow input of num_folds to ClassImbalanceDataCheck

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Brought up in [this pr](https://github.com/alteryx/evalml/pull/1333/#discussion_r510924733)

Basically, we want to alter AutoMLSearch such that it can determine the num_cv_folds of the datasplitter, and pass this value in to `ClassImbalanceDataCheck`. Right now, we default to 3, but if a user defines a custom data split strategy with `num_cv_folds = 4`, and calls our default data checks, the resulting check would assume 3 folds, and error messages would print as `2 * number of cross folds = 6` rather than `8`.

title: OHE not deterministic when fit multiple times with top_n < number categories

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Repro:

```python
from evalml.pipelines.components import OneHotEncoder
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({"categories": ["cat_1"] * 5 + ["cat_2"] * 4 + ["cat_3"]*3 + ["cat_4"]*3 + ["cat_5"]*3})
ohe = OneHotEncoder(top_n=4, random_state=5)
df1 = ohe.fit_transform(df)
df2 = ohe.fit_transform(df)
pd.testing.assert_frame_equal(df1, df2)
```

Users would expect the OHE fit on the same data to produce the same results. This can cause the results of pipelines fit multiple times on the same data to not be deterministic because the data coming out of the OHE is slightly different each time.

I think part of the cause is that every time we call `sample`  in the OHE fit method we mutate the random state.

title: Poor performance on diamond dataset

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Automl yields models with negative R2.

**Repro**
Dataset [here](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:x:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/EVJqRYjya5JPmr-xlHDEM08BC4cdo4wgP_WfVubuoGpgaw?e=HeMaw4).
```python
import evalml
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
df = pd.read_csv('stones_encoded_small.csv')
y = df.pop('total_sales_price')
automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(problem_type='regression')
automl.search(df, y)
```
Data checks will fail due to highly null / single-value columns. You can disable them with `data_checks='disabled'`. Or, to address them and continue:
```python
cols_to_drop = ['culet_condition', 'fancy_color_dominant_color', 'fancy_color_intensity', 'fancy_color_overtone', 'fancy_color_secondary_color', 'fluor_color', 'image_file_url', 'diamond_id', 'currency_code', 'currency_symbol', 'fancy_color_dominant_color', 'fancy_color_intensity', 'fancy_color_overtone', 'fancy_color_secondary_color', 'has_sarineloupe']
df.drop(columns=cols_to_drop, inplace=True)
automl = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(problem_type='regression')
automl.search(df, y)
```
The results are highly similar either way: negative R2 values for all models, i.e. the models can't produce meaningful results.

Switching the metric to MSE and MAE yields similarly poor models.

**Discussion**
My first suspicion is that the features aren't getting the right type. When I look at the dtypes inferred by pandas, I see many are set as `float64` but only have a few unique values, i.e. they should be set as categorical. I gave that a shot but it didn't seem to change the model results, so there's more to the story.

title: `TerminatedWorker` error when running StackedEnsemble components on CircleCI with `n_jobs!=1`

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
#1134 added two new StackedEnsemble components, but with a caveat: `n_jobs = 1` is a must to prevent running into odd CircleCI errors (see [here](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/alteryx/evalml/6059/workflows/7c03ae25-1941-4852-aa61-7fbb87bc6f0b/jobs/64413)).

This is obviously a limitation, and we should try to figure out the underlying issue! I could not repro this on my local machine, nor my SSH'ing into a failed job's environment.

Potentially relevant issue: scikit-learn-contrib/skope-rules#18

Issue could be related to our scikit-learn wrapper and figuring out how to make our wrapper object scikit-learn compliant (passes `check_estimator`). I tried looking into what extra work would be necessary to do so but I think there would be a lot that would have to change with our current API (for pipelines) before we could make this work.

title: XGBoost estimators not actually using learning rate

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
The evalml XGBoost estimators seem to be using eta instead of learning_rate  as the name for the learning rate parameter (which is named learning_rate in the xgboost package's sklearn api). As a result, it doesn't seem to be using the learning rate parameter at all (only using the default one). Minimal example:
```
from evalml.pipelines import XGBoostClassifier
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=1000)
clf1 = XGBoostClassifier(eta=.001).fit(X, y)
clf2 = XGBoostClassifier(eta=1).fit(X, y)
all(clf1.predict(X) == clf2.predict(X))
# >>> True
# compared with expected
clf3 = XGBoostClassifier(learning_rate=.001).fit(X, y)
clf4 = XGBoostClassifier(learning_rate=1).fit(X, y)
all(clf3.predict(X) == clf4.predict(X))
# >>> False
```
Relevant documentation: https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python/python_api.html#xgboost.XGBClassifier. Source line: https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/components/estimators/classifiers/xgboost_classifier.py#L30, https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/main/evalml/pipelines/components/estimators/regressors/xgboost_regressor.py#L15

title: AutoML: pass random_state to the created pipeline instances

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
I was digging through the code with @piguy314159265 and [we noticed that `IterativeAlgorithm.next_batch` doesn't initialize pipeline instances with a `random_state` value.](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_algorithm/iterative_algorithm.py#L60)

**Symptom**
In short, artificially decreased variance in the modeling results.

Suppose we call automl search two times, the first time with the default `random_state` of 0, and the second time with a custom value, like 42. The two calls will generate different data splits, and the automl tuners (after the first batch) could select different pipelines and generate different parameters for those pipelines. That's fine. But, for the first batch at least, the pipelines which use default parameters will run *with the same random seed both times*.

Most users wouldn't notice this. However, it means some of our performance testing results may have higher variance than our results to date have reported. Our perf tests are supposed to run each trial with a different random seed. After this issue is fixed, the pipelines will also run with a different random seed.

**Fix**
[Update IterativeAlgorithm](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/main/evalml/automl/automl_algorithm/iterative_algorithm.py#L60) to pass down the random seed when creating pipeline instances:
```python
pipeline_class(parameters=self._transform_parameters(pipeline_class, proposed_parameters), random_state=self._random_state)
```

Once we do this, we should do some performance testing to see what the impact is. My recommendation: 20 trials each on the small datasets yaml. Note we also have to resolve [a similar issue in the perf test code](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml_looking_glass/issues/98) before we can test this.

title: Remove CategoricalEncoder base class and get_feature_names function

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
The `get_feature_names` accessor doesn't work, now that our one-hot encoder is more than a wrapper around the sklearn one-hot encoder, and we aren't using the `component_obj` code path for it.

Repro
```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import evalml
X, y = evalml.demos.load_breast_cancer()
ohe = evalml.pipelines.components.OneHotEncoder()
ohe.fit(X, y=y)
ohe.get_feature_names()
```

Results in
```python
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'feature_names'
```

**Proposal**
Let's delete `get_feature_names`. We have a different API in place for accessing the list of the names of the features provided to each component in a pipeline.

At that point, `CategoricalEncoder` is just an empty class only referenced by one other piece of code. So we should remove it.

body:
## Problem
#### Context: 
- I've configured a cost benefit matrix objective with **true positives** to be the only positive value. 
- Training data labels: 37%
- Test data labels are 22% True

#### Expected Outcome: 
Pipeline always predicts True or predicts some True

#### Actual Outcome
Pipeline always predicts always predicts False

## Reproducer
[Training data](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:x:/g/personal/ethan_tu_alteryx_com/EVIoX960o69CqM7-y03AFd8B6ZBt89-CUc63KZGtmvaHjA?e=0TG1CE)
[Test data](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:x:/g/personal/ethan_tu_alteryx_com/EeLRYHRQ3dRPvbdWHKSjOiIBaiQ_jtYMMxcKOfhAwHsUBQ?e=pR8V7Q)

#### Code
```
X_train = read.csv(train.csv)
y_train = X_train.pop('label')
X_test = read.csv(test.csv)
y_test = X_test.pop('label')

cost_benefit_matrix = CostBenefitMatrix(true_positive=1000, true_negative=0,
                        false_positive=0, false_negative=0)

automl = AutoMLSearch(problem_type='binary',
                      objective=cost_benefit_matrix,
                      max_pipelines=20)

automl.search(X_train, y_train)
pipeline = automl.best_pipeline
pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)
pipeline.score(X_test, y_test, objectives=[cost_benefit_matrix])

```

## Symptoms

sum(pipeline.predict(X_test)) == 0
#### Pipeline doesn't do well on the objective
pipeline.score(X_test, y_test, objectives=[cost_benefit_matrix]) == OrderedDict([('Cost Benefit Matrix', 0.0)])

title: Boolean column to Imputer breaks if it is the only categorical column

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
If only a boolean column is passed to a SimpleImputer, or if a boolean column is the only non-numeric column passed to an Imputer, it breaks:

Repro: the following code fails with a `ValueError: SimpleImputer does not support data with dtype bool. Please provide either a numeric array (with a floating point or integer dtype) or categorical data represented either as an array with integer dtype or an array of string values with an object dtype.` check.
```
X = pd.DataFrame({
        "bool col with nan": pd.Series([True, np.nan, False, np.nan, True], dtype='bool'),
    })
imputer = Imputer()
imputer.fit(X, y)
```

However, as soon as we add another column (object, category, with or without np.nan), the imputer works fine:
```
X = pd.DataFrame({
        "object with nan": ["b", "b", np.nan, "c", np.nan],
        "bool col with nan": pd.Series([True, np.nan, False, np.nan, True], dtype='bool'),
    })
imputer = Imputer()
imputer.fit(X, y)
```

The stack trace is as follows:

~/Desktop/evalml/evalml/utils/base_meta.py in _set_fit(self, X, y)

---> 14             return_value = method(self, X, y)
