title: Support non-numeric columns in one-way Partial Dependency

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
### Non-Numeric Columns and one-way Partial Dependency

- As a developer, I want to calculate the one-way partial dependency for each feature in my holdout data. I want to better understand the relation between each of the features.
- In many cases, my dataset contains non-numeric columns, like categoricals, datetimes, and naturallanguage. As a ML scientist, I want AutoML search to handle these data types when calculating partial dependency.


## Example
```python
import evalml
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.model_understanding.graphs import partial_dependence
from featuretools.demo import load_retail
from evalml.model_family import ModelFamily, handle_model_family

X_y = load_retail(nrows=1000, return_single_table=True)
X = X_y.drop(columns=['total'])
y = X_y['total']

automl = AutoMLSearch(problem_type="regression", objective="auto", max_pipelines=5)
X_train, X_holdout, y_train, y_holdout = evalml.preprocessing.split_data(X, y, 
                                                                         test_size=0.2,
                                                                         regression=True)
automl.search(X_train, y_train)
for x in automl.rankings['id']:
    pipeline = automl.get_pipeline(x)
    if pipeline.model_family != ModelFamily.BASELINE:
        pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)
        # quantity is a numeric field
        # But cannot calculate partial dependency since  some other columns in X are non-numeric
        try:
            data = partial_dependence(pipeline, X_holdout, feature='quantity')
        except Exception as e:
            print(e)
```

## Errors
```
Invalid cat_features[6] = 9 value: index must be < 9.
could not convert string to float: 'C536391'
could not convert string to float: 'C536391'
This XGBRegressor instance is not fitted yet. Call 'fit' with appropriate arguments before using this estimator.
```

title: LightGBM component doesn't support non-numeric targets

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body: Currently, the LightGBM implementation doesn't handle outputs if they aren't {0, 1} values for binary classification. Incorporating `LabelEncoder` to automatically encode this, like in `catboost`, would be required.

title: XGBoost and one-way Partial Dependency

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
### XGBoost and one-way Partial Dependency

- As a developer, I want to calculate the one-way partial dependency for each feature in my holdout data. I want to better understand the relation between each of the features.
- Therefore, I tried to take all models generated by AutoML Search, and generating partial dependency values. I got an error when I tried to run the Partial dependency for the XGBOOST pipeline.
- Reproducible example. 

```python
import evalml
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
from evalml.model_understanding.graphs import (
    partial_dependence
)
X, y = evalml.demos.load_breast_cancer()
automl = AutoMLSearch(problem_type="binary", objective="f1", max_pipelines=5)
X_train, X_holdout, y_train, y_holdout = evalml.preprocessing.split_data(X, y, test_size=.2)
automl.search(X_train, y_train)

for id_ in automl.rankings['id'].values:
    pipeline = automl.get_pipeline(id_)
    # to show bug, only getting XGBOOST pipeline
    if pipeline.model_family == ModelFamily.XGBOOST:
        pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)
        for col in X_holdout.columns:
            print(col)
            print(partial_dependence(pipeline, X_holdout, feature=0))
```

        # This is a hack, but is necessary in order for the Python SDK to resolve the DLL

                    problem_type=problem_type,
                    max_pipelines=int(
                        self.provider.tool_config["max_pipelines_search"]
                    ),

                    additional_objectives=[],

                    n_jobs=1,
                )
            except Exception as e:
                self.provider.io.error(
                    self.xmsg(f"Pipeline search failed with error: '{str(e)}'")
                )

        # get top pipeline
        top_pipeline_id = automl.rankings["id"].tolist()[0]

        # Fit pipeline with all data
        pipeline = automl.get_pipeline(top_pipeline_id)

        try:
            # Hack to force fitting jobs to be single threaded so the SDK won't reject it.
            from joblib import parallel_backend

            with parallel_backend("threading", n_jobs=1):

                pipeline_entity = EvalMLPipelineEntity(
                    target=self.target_metadata,
                    training_features=list(X),
                    pipeline=pipeline.fit(X, y),
                    target_classes=None,
                )

        except Exception as e:
            self.provider.io.error(
                self.xmsg(f"Fitting the model failed with error: '{str(e)}'")

            return

When I drop the nulls from the same dataset, this code all works as expected. Currently, the AutoML tool in Designer fails on the training step when there are nulls in the dataset, and no model is returned.

title: Flaky text unit tests

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Test `test_featurizer_only_text(text_df)` in file `evalml/tests/component_tests/test_text_featurizer.py` fails due to a reference before assignment. This test fails occasionally, as I ran into it only once out of many runs. 

see: [circleci test](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/FeatureLabs/evalml/5310/workflows/6dd53f78-da54-4ae7-a953-9b9784415eb3/jobs/54457)

Error was: `NameError: free variable 'swords' referenced before assignment in enclosing scope`

title: Regression pipeline producing negative r2 values and 0 MSE values

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
## Problem

- Optimizing for r2 values gives a negative number. r2 values should range from 0-1
- Optimizing for mse values gives every pipeline a score of 0

## Reproducibility

### Code
```
X = read_csv('evalml_r2_mse_bug.csv')
y = X.pop('permutation_importance')
automl = AutoMLSearch(problem_type='regression', objective='r2', max_pipelines=5)
automl.search(X, y)
```
### Data
https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/ethan_tu_alteryx_com/EbgALrR9W2pKhpBicJ1QIxMBZ957YK5S13evLMi9mAXS5Q?e=4Z2YmF

## Symptoms
The baseline mean model is always the best performing

title: Imputer cannot fit when there is None in a categorical or boolean column

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
## Reproducer
```python
from evalml.pipelines.components import Imputer
df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, 3], "b": ["1", "2", None]})
imputer = Imputer()
imputer.fit(df)
```

```python

title: OneHotEncoder introduces NaNs when dataframe has custom index

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
## Reproducer:
```python
from evalml.pipelines.components import OneHotEncoder
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1]*100, "b": ["foo"] * 50 + ["bar"] * 50}, index=range(100, 200))
ohe = OneHotEncoder()

ohe.fit(df)

ohe.transform(df)
```

## Output:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41651716/90661130-cf198180-e214-11ea-91df-81c17639ebe0.png)


I think the issue is the call to `reindex` (it introduces NaNs when there is no value in the new index). Maybe we should just pass in the index of `X_t` when `X_cat` is being created?

title: TextFeaturizer produces NaN values if input row is missing alphanumeric characters

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
In work on [integrating the TextFeaturizer into automl](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/compare/908_integrate_text), I found that putting the TextFeaturizer after the Imputer but before the OneHotEncoder will cause the OneHotEncoder to throw an error due to the existence of NaN(s) in the input data for some datasets. 

The offending row in question contained text that was simply ":)". Since the TextFeaturizer removes punctuation, this was getting passed in as an empty string, and therefore the primitive `MEAN_CHARACTERS_PER_WORD" was null. We need a way to prevent this from throwing an error, since the order of `Imputer >> TextFeaturizer >> OneHotEncoder` is the desired order of component operations.

title: Fix Imputer indexing when sklearn imputer drops a row

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Background**
We just merged an updated `Imputer` in #991 , which handles numeric/categorical separately. And we're using that in automl instead of `SimpleImputer`, which is deprecated

**Problem**
Suppose the index of the training dataframe doesn't range from 0 to `n-1`. In that case, `SimpleImputer` ends up resetting the index to range from 0 to `n-1`. However, `Imputer` does not. This causes the one-hot encoder to fill in the missing rows, causing issues with the estimators. The most visible symptom is that `RandomForestClassifier` produces a stack trace during automl search.

**Repro**
```python
import pandas as pd
import evalml
from evalml import AutoMLSearch
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

df = pd.read_csv("~/Downloads/titanic3.csv")
non_null = ~pd.isnull(df['survived'])
df = df[non_null]
y = df["survived"]
X = df.drop("survived", axis=1)
# this is what messes with the indexes -- train_test_split doesn't reset them
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2, stratify=y, random_state=0)

pipeline_class = evalml.pipelines.utils.make_pipeline(
    X_train, y_train,
    evalml.pipelines.components.estimators.classifiers.RandomForestClassifier,
    'binary')
pipeline = pipeline_class(parameters={})
# the call to fit fails
pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)
```

**Fix**
Have `Imputer` reset index at the end of `transform`

title: Imputer: same fill value used for numeric/categorical for "constant" strategy

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body: Following #991, we separated out impute strategies based on data type (numeric vs categorical), but they still share the same `fill_value` parameter. It could be useful to have two separate parameters for this, or at the very least, provide checks that the `fill_value` is applicable to both types of data.

title: UnboundLocalError: local variable 'cv_pipeline' referenced before assignment when error in automl search

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Reproducible example:
```python
from evalml.pipelines import MulticlassClassificationPipeline

from evalml.pipelines.components import Transformer

X, y = load_wine()
class NewTransformer(Transformer):
    name = 'New Transformer'
    hyperparameter_ranges = {
        "parameter_1":['a', 'b', 'c']
    }

    def __init__(self, random_state):
        parameters = {"parameter_1": "a"}
        super().__init__(parameters=parameters,
                         component_obj=None,
                         random_state=random_state)

class CustomMulticlassClassificationPipeline(MulticlassClassificationPipeline):
    component_graph = [NewTransformer, 'Random Forest Classifier']

automl_custom = evalml.automl.AutoMLSearch(problem_type='multiclass', max_pipelines=2, allowed_pipelines=[CustomMulticlassClassificationPipeline])
automl_custom.search(X, y)
```

Trivial example but I think still valid: `cv_pipeline` is initialized in the try above and thus raises an `UnboundLocalError: local variable 'cv_pipeline'` if we error out before hitting that line.

title: Can't run text featurizer without network connection

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body: Currently, [the LSA nlp primitive uses the `nltk` library to download a text corpus to support TF-IDF](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/nlp_primitives/blob/master/nlp_primitives/lsa.py#L59). We should be able to generate text features without a network connection. So let's find a way to either do that download in advance when we package evalml, or to avoid having to do it in the first place.

title: Flaky test in text featurizer

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to testing.

body:
In [this recent job](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/FeatureLabs/evalml/4694/workflows/b4264f60-4ac5-4ad2-8245-8dcc0afa847a/jobs/46424), on a branch with no related changes, `evalml.tests.component_tests.test_text_featurization::test_lsa_primitive_output` failed: `evalml/tests/component_tests/test_text_featurization.py:199: AssertionError: Arrays are not almost equal to 3 decimals`

My hope is that this failure happened because the TF-IDF currently relies on `nltk` downloading a corpus over the network.. We've noticed circleci has been having network issues lately, which has caused some jobs to fail. And therefore fixing #926 would fix this.

If that's not the problem, perhaps rewriting the test will fix this. I wonder if something in that code isn't respecting the random seed, or one of the dependent libraries has a race condition.

title: Error in pip install and warning on import after adding text/featuretools

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: blocker
labels.description: An issue blocking a release.

body:
**Background**
#913 added a text preprocessing component using the `nlp-primitives` package built off `featuretools`

**Problem**
During pip install we now get the following error:
```
ERROR: tensorflow 2.2.0 has requirement scipy==1.4.1; python_version >= "3", but you'll have scipy 1.5.1 which is incompatible.
```
Whenever we try to import evalml we get this error:
```
2020-07-10 21:00:46,434 featuretools - WARNING    Featuretools failed to load plugin nlp_primitives from library nlp_primitives. For a full stack trace, set logging to debug.
```

These could be symptoms of the same issue, or there could be two bugs.

Both as seen [in this recent job on `main`](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/FeatureLabs/evalml/4580/workflows/c7e0a9c8-9c07-445a-b39d-b2a11e8fd49a/jobs/44927)

**Backup option if we can't quickly find a fix**
We can always back out the text component, debug this and add it back in when its ready.

title: Add Datacheck to check for single target value

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body: Currently, data checks pass when there is only one unique value in the target labels passed to the AutoML Search function, even though that causes an error later on. For example, if the target labels were `[30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30]`, the default data checks pass, but an `IndexError: single positional indexer is out-of-bounds` error is generated later on by pandas, (last point in the evalml library is in the pipeline class). I have attached an image of the stack trace for this error. We should create a `Datacheck` for this case, to ensure that the error message is helpful and relevant rather than caused later on with a cryptic and seemingly unrelated error message. The main decision that has to be made to solve this issue is whether to add a new data check to the set of default data checks, or to add this specific case to an existing data check. Currently, there is a target checker in place, so if going with the second option, it would likely make the most sense to add to this checker.

title: One-hot encoder breaks for any string/categorical-typed inputs

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: blocker
labels.description: An issue blocking a release.

body:
Minimal repo:

```
automl = AutoClassificationSearch(max_pipelines=10, allowed_pipelines=None)
X = pd.DataFrame([[1, "a", np.nan], [2, "b", np.nan], [5, "b", np.nan], [5, "b", np.nan]])
y = pd.Series([0, 0, 1, 1])
automl.search(X, y)
```

Gives this error:
```

~/Desktop/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sklearn/preprocessing/_encoders.py in get_feature_names(self, input_features)
    535         for i in range(len(cats)):
    536             names = [
--> 537                 input_features[i] + '_' + str(t) for t in cats[i]]
    538             if self.drop is not None:
    539                 names.pop(self.drop_idx_[i])

~/Desktop/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sklearn/preprocessing/_encoders.py in <listcomp>(.0)
    535         for i in range(len(cats)):
    536             names = [
--> 537                 input_features[i] + '_' + str(t) for t in cats[i]]
    538             if self.drop is not None:
    539                 names.pop(self.drop_idx_[i])

UFuncTypeError: ufunc 'add' did not contain a loop with signature matching types (dtype('<U21'), dtype('<U21')) -> dtype('<U21')
```
Brief search led me to [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44527956/python-ufunc-add-did-not-contain-a-loop-with-signature-matching-types-dtype), so maybe has something to do with sklearn handling as numpy and the input type being strings? Not too sure though, didn't look too much into this!

title: AutoML can configure SimpleImputer to apply invalid imputation for categorical dtype

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: blocker
labels.description: An issue blocking a release.

body:
**Problem**
I think the current symptom: the tuner will include 'mean' and 'median' imputation strategies and try to recommend those for categoricals.

First step: confirm this is in fact the case. Either post a description of the code path to produce the problem or make a simple reproducer.

**Fixes**
We've had recent discussions about this in slack ( @angela97lin , @jeremyliweishih ). The long-term fix is to properly support datatypes in evalml. Some options for short-term fix:
1. Limit `SimpleImputer` to only `mode` imputation
2. Add a `dtype` parameter to `SimpleImputer` which means it'll only apply to that datatype
3. Update `SimpleImputer` to have a different imputation strategy field for each supported datatype. And update the hyperparameter ranges to match.

Datatypes we should support in the short-term: numeric, categorical, datetime. Longer-term: text

**Timeline**
Once confirmed, we should fix this before the June release goes out.

title: Components and pipelines: standardize error when calling predict/transform before fit

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Currently different pipelines/components have different behavior when you call `predict`/`transform` before calling `fit`. All our pipelines and components should throw the same error in this case.

Ideas:
* Have all components do their own check for this in `predict`/`transform`, but throw the same exception, `UntrainedPredictError`
* Have all components' `predict` or `transform` methods call `super().predict(...)` etc at the beginning. Not sure if this is a good idea though, because there's probably some components for which this doesn't make sense. Plus this wouldn't support custom components well--what if someone forgot to do this?
* I wonder if we could do this with a decorator, or a metaclass if necessary.

I kind of like the idea of a decorator, assuming that works. Someone could still forget to set the decorator in a custom component though.

Next steps: decide on the plan

--> 153         ret = um.true_divide(
    154                 ret, rcount, out=ret, casting='unsafe', subok=False)
    155         if is_float16_result and out is None:

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'str' and 'int'
```

Code to reproduce:

```python
data = pd.read_csv("iris.csv")
target = "class"
X = data.drop([target], axis=1)
y = data[target]
automl = AutoClassificationSearch(multiclass=True)
automl.search(X, y)
```

I'm only able to reproduce this issue with the iris dataset and the abalone dataset with "sex" set as the target variable. In both cases, the target variable is categorical but all predictor variables are continuous. That is currently the only hypothesis I have on why these two datasets trigger the error but other data sets don't seem to.

title: Automl: if any provided objective errors, all computed scores are nan

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
As raised in #785, and with the addition of RMSLE and MSLE as in #728, there will be more errors potentially raised when using objective functions to evaluate a model. In the case where the main objective errors out on the given data, it makes sense that that objective should not be used, and the program should throw an error. However, when there is an error in an `additional_objective`, it probably makes more sense to just have `nan` for that metric only. However, right now, if an exception is raised for any metric, regardless if it is the main metric or an additional one, the code in `auto_search_base.py` is such that this will cause all values in the scores field, for every metric, will be `nan`. Particularly in the case where the additional metrics might error often on certain types of data, it would make more sense for the `nan` just to be set for the score of those additional metrics, rather than invalidating the whole search score. 

One possible way to solve this might be to move the exception catching and resulting scoring individually from [`auto_search_base._evaluate`](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/5a5270d384b5d6a898db4c76e7c0e902a0be8a7f/evalml/automl/auto_search_base.py#L320) into the [`pipeline_base.score`](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/5a5270d384b5d6a898db4c76e7c0e902a0be8a7f/evalml/pipelines/pipeline_base.py#L213) function, so that the na result be assigned to individual metrics rather than all of them at once.

This is currently somewhat blocking #728, as the MSLE and RMSLE cannot be added to the dictionary of default possible linear regression metrics when they throw errors and disrupt the use of any linear regression that might have negative values.

title: Fail codecov job if upload to codecov.io is unsuccessful

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to testing.

body:
**Background**
I put up a PR today to update our expected test dependencies (#748). Codecov failed, and on further investigation I noticed that [one of the jobs](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/FeatureLabs/evalml/3512/workflows/4b21c30e-0b18-4b6f-b668-c8336086e6e8/jobs/31108/steps) which uploads coverage reporting to codecov.io had timed out when sending to codecov.io:
```
==> Uploading
    .url https://codecov.io
    .query commit=e79090f6766f5a935c6518555271629778d3de16&branch=dep-update&job=31108.0&token=<secret>&service=circleci&build=31108.0&slug=FeatureLabs%2Fevalml&package=py2.0.15
    Pinging Codecov...
Error: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='codecov.io', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /upload/v4?commit=e79090f6766f5a935c6518555271629778d3de16&branch=dep-update&job=31108.0&token=************************************&service=circleci&build=31108.0&slug=FeatureLabs%2Fevalml&package=py2.0.15 (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7f39d1bdcac0>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno 110] Connection timed out'))
```

Looks like it was a networking error.

However, the circleci job in which that job ran (which happened to be the linux 3.8 unit tests with minimal deps) was still marked as green. That's bad, because then when the codecov report was generated, it was missing the minimal deps coverage, but there was no way to tell without digging into the logs

**Solution**
If codecov fails to upload for some reason, we should mark the job as failed.

It looks like [the `codecov` bash uploader we use](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/master/.circleci/config.yml#L185) [doesn't return a nonzero error code by default](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-the-codecov-bash-uploader). We should change that.

title: KeyError for `automl.rankings` when no search is ran

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body: If `automl.rankings` is called before a search takes place, the below `KeyError` is thrown directly to the user. This was seen [here](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/pull/675#discussion_r420174624) since there is no clean way to check if a search has been performed. The likely cause of this is the fact that rankings is a `@property` so it is calculated when it is first called. As mentioned by @dsherry [here](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/pull/675#discussion_r420228907), one solution would be to add another property that checks if a run has been created. If not, then the `rankings` property function would throw a cleaner error message.

title: PR checkin tests: codecov occasionally passes when it should actually fail

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: testing
labels.description: Issues related to testing.

body:
**Problem**
@angela97lin 's PR #711 added a change which, in retrospect, should've caused codecov to fail. But the last run of the codecov test in the PR checkin tests came back green. Angela noticed [the codecov job failed on master](https://codecov.io/gh/FeatureLabs/evalml/commit/5dabe7e64c4dca7bf4c068428c1fb071e83b3bec) after the PR was merged, and got #730 up to fix the issue.

On closer inspection, it appears the last run of codecov on #711 [diff'd a hash against itself](https://codecov.io/gh/FeatureLabs/evalml/compare/4c40d8e1f81964a087ead457bb4838ffdff49968...4c40d8e1f81964a087ead457bb4838ffdff49968), which doesn't make any sense, thus resulting in the green status from the checkin test job. The hash used was the last commit on Angela's branch for the PR.

However, when I look up PR #711 in the codecov.io UI, I see [a codecov report](https://codecov.io/gh/FeatureLabs/evalml/pull/711) where a) the correct hashes are used in the diff and b) the status is red, as we'd expect for that change.

**Symptoms and scope**
Occasionally (unknown how frequently), the PR checkin test codecov jobs could be erroneously running the codecov diff against themselves and completing as green.

This appears to only apply to the PR checkin tests, and doesn't affect the codecov job which runs on merges to master.

**Hypothesis**
I've noticed the codecov bot will post on PRs a couple minutes after the PR is created but before the unit tests have completed and codecov can be generated from them. I'm suspicious that the bot is causing this problem somehow.

**Temporary solution**
Before merging PRs, we can all manually inspect the codecov diff in the PR and ensure it looks correct and isn't diffing a hash against itself.

**Next steps**
We should see if we can find any mention of this online. We should take a look at the codecov bot settings. We can also create a dummy PR which deletes some unit tests and pay careful attention when we put up the PR and make updates to it, to see if we can recreate this issue and learn any further details. If all else fails, we can contact codecov support.

title: Performance issues on objectives feature branch: computing predict more than once

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Issues tracking performance improvements.

body: **Problem** On the `improved_objectives` branch, we're computing each pipeline's predictions *three* times during automl search, vs once on `master`. **Symptoms** We've noticed the RTD docs have been timing out on the `improved_objectives` branch as we're trying to merge it, even after we cut the build time a bunch. We also noticed cell execution timeouts on some of the notebooks during docs generation, meaning they took longer than 5min to run.We've also noticed unit test execution time is up [from 4min on python3.8 on master](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/FeatureLabs/evalml/2786/workflows/60526f11-b17d-4971-93a6-8038d2965176/jobs/21723) to [just over 6min on `improved_objectives`](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/FeatureLabs/evalml/2798/workflows/f1307909-1285-4642-b928-5612e7c09d78/jobs/21879). **Hypotheses** I reviewed the current diff (#445 ) of `improved_objectives` with `master`, and noticed the following changes which could contribute to a slowdown: 1. Plot metrics On `improved_objectives`, [we're computing ROC and confusion matrix data for every bin class pipeline](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/pull/445/files#diff-966f722c721e24f671fa821edbf6a160R307). We [compute these on `master` too](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/master/evalml/automl/auto_base.py#L293), in the same loop as for the other additional objectives. But on `improved_objectives` we compute the predictions a second time inside `PipelineBase.get_plot_data`, because ROC/confusion are no longer in the same loop as the objectives. 2. Optimize threshold On `master`, we currently only optimize the binary classification threshold for custom objectives. On `improved_objectives`, we now optimize the binary classification threshold for most binary objectives (not AUC/logloss). This is a cool feature. The problem is, on `improved_objectives`, we [compute the predicted probabilities for the threshold optimization](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/pull/445/files#diff-966f722c721e24f671fa821edbf6a160R302), then we [do the same again inside the call to `PipelineBase.score`](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/pull/445/files#diff-966f722c721e24f671fa821edbf6a160R305). **Profiling** I did some comparative profiling between `improved_objectives` and `master`. On each, I ran a 5-pipeline automl search with demo binary classification data using [cProfile](https://docs.python.org/3/library/profile.html#module-cProfile), then plotted the results in [snakeviz](https://jiffyclub.github.io/snakeviz/). Profile outputs downloadable here: [`master`](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/Eb63ehDDth5EpueBhKy0FssBoid_A3LVJ6kTcWmzgXSgRA?e=r2tqDG), [`improved_objectives`](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/EcqwkWGX-FpAjfDG5j5u9KcBMiNa-aqJf2IzHdnwE76R7g?e=avUWYk) 1. I found that on `improved_objectives`, we spend an extra 33% of time on `PipelineBase.get_plot_data`, recomputing predictions. 2. Of the total 45sec profiled, we only spend less than 1sec on threshold optimization, so that doesn't seem to be a blocking issue right now. However, we do spend what looks like another 10% of extra time recomputing predictions inside `PipelineBase.score` which we already computed in `AutoBase._do_iteration` for `optimize_threshold`, so that's not great. In short the profiling confirms my hypotheses. **Recommendations** * Delete `PipelineBase.get_plot_data` from `AutoBase` and the search results. Let's not compute that data during automl. That'll buy us back the extra 33%. File another issue to figure out how to support generating this data in the future. * Delete the `optimize_threshold` functionality from `AutoBase` for now. File another issue to add it back in once we get the feature branch in. My thought on how to do this later: add basic memoization, even if its a bit hacky and specific to `PipelineBase.predict`/`predict_proba`. * Then we can merge `improved_objectives` into `master` * Long-term, this is solid evidence that memoizing predictions (#466) would be useful and would also save us confusing bugs like this. * We should have a test which monitors overall timing in some way. Perhaps this responsibility should simply fall to the perf tests. If we had perf tests with overall timing coverage as part of our process today, they would have showed us this time increase sooner. **Images** Profiling `AutoBase._do_iteration` on `master`: And on `improved_objectives`: [The test file I profiled.](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/ESWv9yv6hJtChiI73NlTLtcBpicFctaE_u4bP1xcTzcU1w?e=0xFCQW)

title: XGBoostClassifier does not work with feature names that contain [, ], or <

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
A shortcoming of the xgboost package is that it does not support feature names that contain `[`, `]`, or `<`.

E.g.
```
import numpy as np

import pandas as pd

from evalml.pipelines.components import XGBoostClassifier

np.random.seed(442)
nrows = 100
ncols = 2
X = np.random.normal(size=(nrows, ncols))
X_good = pd.DataFrame(X_arr)
X_bad = pd.DataFrame(X_arr, columns=["a<x", "b"])
y = np.random.normal(size=nrows)

XGBoostClassifier().fit(X_good, y)
>>> <...XGBoostClassifier ...>

XGBoostClassifier().fit(X_bad, y)
>>> ValueError ...
```

One way to resolve this would be to wrap the appropriate methods (fit, predict, etc) to convert dataframes into numpy arrays, e.g. with `sklearn.utils.check_array`.

title: Have dependency check bot install same requirements as latest dependency checkin job

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: blocker
labels.description: An issue blocking a release.

body:
**Problem**
Right now, dependency check bot (which uses github actions) installs `core-requirements.txt` and `requirements.txt` but not `test-requirements.txt` like `latest_dependency_check` does in the checkin tests.

**Fix**
We should update these to match, otherwise we'll get problems when we add things to the test reqs.

While we're at it, let's centralize all `pip` commands into the makefile so that we don't run into this sort of issue again.

Remove `category-encoders` for whitelist and `latest_dependecies.txt`

Marked as a blocker because we should fix this before merging more stuff to master to avoid confusion lol

title: Performance issue: catboost (and maybe xgboost) classifier takes significantly longer to run in perf tests

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Issues tracking performance improvements.

body:
**Problem**
The latest performance test results appear to show that the recently-merged random_state change #347 has introduced a significant slowdown in `AutoClassificationSearch.search` completion time. From a quick glance at the logs, it appears the culprit in particular is `catboost`.

From `stockmarket_test_auc`, python 3.8, after #347:
```
▹ Cat Boost Classification Pipeline:        70%|███████   | Elapsed:01:40
✔ Cat Boost Classification Pipeline:        70%|███████   | Elapsed:06:15
✔ Cat Boost Classification Pipeline:        80%|████████  | Elapsed:06:15
```

**Scope**
We have yet to confirm the scope of this issue. At first glance, it's most likely specific to catboost. It may even simply be a problem with the configuration of our perf test machines as opposed to an actual bug with our code.

It may also apply to xgboost, but we don't have any timing information for that pipeline because it never ran before #347.

**Background**
#347 made every call to a random number generator in our codebase stem from the input seed, and added support for accepting `np.random.RandomState` objects as well as integer seeds. Therefore, it changed the order of calls to the random number generator, which would produce changes in the results from individual training runs with fixed seeds.

Prior to #347, the catboost classification estimator was not passed a random seed at all. The catboost regression estimator was, although now that seed will be different. Same for the xgboost classifier: it was being passed a seed, but the value will have changed internally. Xgboost and catboost require integer seeds as input, so #347 calls `np.random.RandomState.randint` to get the seed for those estimators.

**Results**
[Here are the perf test results](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/EdQYZfl3g7lJtxoS9WqqA2YBY4L06Nt1ammRGFgm8CkjVQ?e=yQQqqm), including all run logs. [Here's the generated results summary](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/EcUH2vfp4yVFv1QbzsFEv9kBb4GDxSTpatfto7EYeCgZ5w?e=hYM2nN) with the plots. These results compare the v0.8.0 release candidate to v0.7.0. Observe the increase in runtime in the results summary, particularly for the multiclass problem `covtype_test_f1_weighted`. 4 of the 5 problems had a slowdown, with the exception of `property_assessment_test_r2 ` which had a slight speedup.

There are slight changes in the reported leaderboard accuracies, but nothing too concerning.

Chris also [ran the perf tests on the commit before #347](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/EVfAc4Yn0whOkaothK-VtK0BjYYZi7u1cUiCP5YQuMy8VQ?e=OMz6Tp), which is helpful info to have. Here's the summary for that. Those results show no change in runtime.

I did some local testing on my machine. I ran the catboost classification pipeline on binary classification data for 20 different seeds, both before and after the random_state change, and measured the time to fit and score. No significant difference was observed. My script is [here](https://alteryx0-my.sharepoint.com/:u:/g/personal/dylan_sherry_alteryx_com/EaBtt_mSEYFMoVkj36oksdUB1SkSA3xtbwuYrA3-xK-b2g?e=vAOduZ); the data was based on the covtype perf test dataset, from the perf test bucket in S3. Results are [attached](https://app.zenhub.com/files/197466539/8f03228b-9a2c-40b1-9dc3-0f1963744797/download).

**Theories**
Our performance tests currently only run one automl search for each problem configuration, and they do so with a fixed seed. That means any change to the random number generators could appear to have a large impact, depending on the overall variance for the problem configuration in question. However, it seems unlikely this alone could explain a consistent slowdown across 4 datasets and 3 python versions.

Perhaps everything is working as intended. We should find out what parameters were used for catboost and xgboost in the case where they took a while to run. With catboost, if n_estimators is high, that could produce slow training time but also more accurate results. It's worth noting that because we always used `random_state=0` in the perf tests before #347, we never ran catboost after the first pipeline, so we don't know if this is really a change in behavior.

Perhaps the perf test machines aren't configured properly for xgboost and catboost. We've had some trouble with that on circleci; we have to set `OMP_NUM_THREADS` for xgboost to not hang. It's also possible there's a bug in our automl code which is causing this, but I don't see how.

Perhaps there's a bug in the perf test code, or some key difference between the code which runs automl before vs after.

It is possible, although it seems unlikely, that the way #347 sets the random seed for catboost is triggering undefined behavior with them.

**Next steps**
Debugging:
* Try the same reproduction steps I did locally on a perf test worker machine. Do some profiling there if we can consistently reproduce the slowness.
* Understand the perf test code which runs automl, and inspect changes to that code from before vs after to see if there are contributing factors there

Performance test improvements:
* Have the perf tests run automl multiple times with different seeds in each test, not just once. Show a timing and accuracy table comparing the mean, std, best before vs after.
* Have direct performance measurements of each pipeline and component in isolation i.e. outside the context of automl. Show a timing and accuracy table for each.
* The performance test code must also use consistent random seeds everywhere, so that we can reliably reproduce any result.

title: `Error in sys.excepthook` during automl unit tests

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

labels.name: needs design
labels.description: Issues requiring design documentation.

body:
This started to surface during unit tests after #491 was merged in. This doesn't affect the tests or cause them to fail but should be fixed regardless. I've boiled the problem down to PipelineBase properties directly accessing it's `cls.component_graph`.

A fix is to make properties (such as `PipelineBase.summary`) access a `copy.copy`-ed `component_graph` instead of working on `cls.component_graph`. 

I see some ways of achieving this:

- Add `component_graph = copy.copy(cls.component_graph` on the top of these methods
- Add variable decorators to make class variables return a copy (a hard to bypass issue here is that decorators are not inherited by subclasses)
- Use a metaclass to make `PipelineBase` pass a copy
- Use a class decorator and `_init_subclass` to make `PipelineBase` pass a copy 

I've done some brainstorming no the branch `js_test_decorators`

title: SimpleImputer fails if data contains None instead of np.nan

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Encountered while working with @rwedge on some customer data.

By default, sklearn's `SimpleImputer` expects "missing values" to be `np.nan`. If a dataframe contains `None` values, sklearn's `SimpleImputer` can throw ugly nonintuitive errors.

```
In [30]: df = pd.DataFrame(pd.Series(['a', 'b', None]))
In [31]: si_sklearn = sklearn.impute.SimpleImputer(strategy='most_frequent')
In [32]: si_sklearn.fit(df)
Out[33]:
TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'NoneType' and 'str'
```
A different but similarly ugly error comes out for numerical data: `ValueError: Input contains NaN, infinity or a value too large for dtype('float64').`

**Notes on fix**
Setting `missing_values=None` in the constructor tells sklearn's SimpleImputer to expect `None` instead of `np.nan`.
```
In [33]: df = pd.DataFrame(pd.Series(['a', 'b', None]))
In [34]: si_sklearn = sklearn.impute.SimpleImputer(strategy='most_frequent', missing_values=None)
In [35]: si_sklearn.fit(df)
Out[35]:
SimpleImputer(add_indicator=False, copy=True, fill_value=None,
              missing_values=None, strategy='most_frequent', verbose=0)
```

Running `X.fill_na(np.nan)` (is that right syntax?) will replace all `None` with `np.nan`.

**Proposed solution**
Short-term: Roy can make that replacement in the customer's data. And let's update our documentation for `SimpleImputer` to instruct people to use `np.nan`. We should also expose the `missing_value` field, with default `np.nan`, although it should definitely not be listed as a tunable hyperparameter.

Long-term: let's add a `DataCheck` for this! The data check should warn about `None`s in the data and suggest the user replace them with `np.nan`. We can even suggest they use `fill_na`.

title: SimpleImputer cannot handle dropped columns

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
SimpleImputer currently fails if we drop any columns during imputation. This is because of the line:

```
X_t = pd.DataFrame(X_t, columns=X.columns).astype(X.dtypes.to_dict())
```
which was put in place to retain column names after imputation (since scikit-learn converts our DataFrame into a numpy array).

Reproducible example: (a bit silly but gets the point across)
```
from evalml.pipelines.components import SimpleImputer

col = pd.Series([np.nan, np.nan, np.nan, np.nan])
X = pd.DataFrame()
X["a"] = col
X["b"] = [1,2,3,4]
X["c"] = col
X["d"] = col
transformer = SimpleImputer(impute_strategy='median')
transformer.fit_transform(X)
```

Arguably, this is something (col with all NaN) we shouldn't run into in the first place, especially if we do some preprocessing checks?

title: Tuner doesn't support non-unique parameter names (across all components in a pipeline)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Currently, the parameters coming back from skopt are a flat list, across all components.

Error case: ComponentA has parameter "C". ComponentB also has parameter "C", although it could do something totally different. Under this scenario, skopt would only optimize and return one value for a parameter named "C"

**Symptoms**
This means that today, we can't have multiple components in one pipeline which share parameter names. If that were to happen, our tuner would be setting the same value for both, even though the parameters could have totally different functions.

**Solutions**
Options:
* Update our `Tuners` class to internally prefix every parameter with the component name (or a unique ID), and then undo that at return time?
* Update our parameters dict in general to use unique component IDs instead of component names (needed for #273 to support multiple components of the same type within one pipeline)

**Problem**
Currently, the "name" field must be entered in the class definition of a new pipeline, but it must exactly match the output of `PipelineBase._generate_name`, otherwise the tuners dict in `AutoBase` gets messed up. And the only way to know the exact name (with an ordering of components matching that generated by `_generate_name`) is to run that function and copy-paste the output.

**Fix**

title: [Discuss] Should target column be input to `Transformer.transform`?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
`Transformer.transform` currently has no `y` arg. But in `PipelineBase._fit` we currently pass a `y` argument to components' `transform` and `fit_transform` methods.

I first encountered this when writing a drop-null transformer. Perhaps it'd want to drop any row with null in the target, not just in the input data. Although, we should really have a data check in place for that and warn/error if the target has null values.

**Question**
Is there a valid use-case for passing `y` into `Transformer.transform`?

**Fix**
If yes, let's add that to `Transformer.transform` as an optional arg. If not, let's remove that arg from the call in `PipelineBase._fit`.

title: Warning messages in unit test: "invalid value encountered in double_scalars" and others

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
**Problem**
Running locally, (on python 3.8, but I've seen similar on other python versions):

```
(featurelabs) ➜  evalml git:(master) pytest -v evalml/tests/automl_tests/test_autobase.py::test_pipeline_limits
====================================================================== test session starts ======================================================================
platform darwin -- Python 3.8.0, pytest-4.4.1, py-1.8.0, pluggy-0.13.1 -- /Users/dsherry/anaconda/envs/featurelabs/bin/python
cachedir: .pytest_cache
rootdir: /Users/dsherry/development/aie/featurelabs/evalml, inifile: setup.cfg
plugins: xdist-1.26.1, cov-2.6.1, nbval-0.9.3, forked-1.1.3
collected 1 item

evalml/tests/automl_tests/test_autobase.py::test_pipeline_limits PASSED       [100%]

======================================================================= warnings summary ========================================================================
evalml/tests/automl_tests/test_autobase.py::test_pipeline_limits
evalml/tests/automl_tests/test_autobase.py::test_pipeline_limits
...
  /Users/dsherry/anaconda/envs/featurelabs/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sklearn/metrics/classification.py:1436: UndefinedMetricWarning:

  Precision is ill-defined and being set to 0.0 due to no predicted samples.
...
  /Users/dsherry/anaconda/envs/featurelabs/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sklearn/metrics/classification.py:1436: UndefinedMetricWarning:

  F-score is ill-defined and being set to 0.0 due to no predicted samples.
...
  /Users/dsherry/anaconda/envs/featurelabs/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sklearn/metrics/classification.py:872: RuntimeWarning:

  invalid value encountered in double_scalars
...
  /Users/dsherry/development/aie/featurelabs/evalml/evalml/automl/auto_base.py:307: RuntimeWarning:

  invalid value encountered in double_scalars
```

Three warnings coming from sklearn and one coming from our code. I seem to get a slightly different combination/order of warnings every time I run the test.

**More info**
[Here's](https://github.com/FeatureLabs/evalml/blob/master/evalml/automl/auto_base.py#L307) the line the last warning is coming from, in `AutoBase._add_result`:
`high_variance_cv = (scores.std() / scores.mean()) > .2`

I suspect `scores` is all empty or all 0. But why? This is the next thing to look into. Perhaps empty test data when we're scoring the model?

My suspicion is that this dataset is too small or too uniform, and that the models trained on it are predicting all the same value or something like that. If I'm right, this reinforces that we need guard rails to detect this problem when the user uploads their data, and that mocking in the unit tests to avoid actual fitting (#275 ) is important (even if this particular test isn't mockable).

I encountered these warnings while debugging bug #167 , so it's possible this is related to that.

**Next steps**
We should determine why these warnings are showing up. If it's a problem with the test setup, let's change the test to fix or avoid it. Otherwise, it could be a bug. We shouldn't be printing out warnings like this under normal use anyways.

labels.name: bug

body:
In our documentation right now, we say that when you call `predict` or `predict_proba` on a pipeline you will get a dataframe or a series. however this isn't that case. 

perhaps we should standardize the component outputs to be dataframes and series. we already standardize the inputs in #61

title: PipelineBase Errors Without Estimator

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issues tracking problems with existing features.

body:
Currently we only check that if there is an estimator it is the last component.
However, the pipeline breaks on fit on the following line without an estimator:
```
self.input_feature_names.update({self.estimator.name: list(pd.DataFrame(X_t))})
```

We should either enforce that all pipelines must have an estimator or fix `_fit` to allow this case.
